business.start.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Alister McMullin) took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: - I direct a question to the Acting Minister for External Affairs. In view of the tremendous importance of reaching an agreement that will result in the opening of the Suez Canal, has the Australian Government given any consideration to the proposals being sponsored by Mr Nikezich, the Yugoslav Foreign Minister, who is at the present time conferring with the British Government?

- 1 have no knowledge of the proposals actually advanced by this gentleman. 1 shall seek from the Department of External Affairs its comments on the question, or the honourable senator may put it on the notice paper.

- 1 direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation. In view of the widespread misunderstanding among the public, will the Minister take steps to make it generally known that persons travelling on commercial airlines arc not automatically insured for £7,500 as implied on air tickets but for only portion thereof - if at all - dependent on a means test principle?

- It is a fact that there is a misunderstanding. Certain requirements have been spelled out in the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act. I think it would be proper in all the circumstances for me to ask that the question be put on the notice paper so that we may get a considered reply in depth from the Minister for Civil Aviation. I ask that that be done. There is quite clearly a misunderstanding on the part of many people in relation to this matter.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate know when the papers relating to flights by VIP aircraft will be tabled, as ordered by the Senate?

- I cannot give the honourable senator a date. I know that a considerable amount of work is proceeding in an endeavour to discover details of the people who have flown in VIP aircraft, the places to which they have flown and at what times. This work is in progress and at the moment 1 cannot give the honourable senator any more definite answer than that.

- Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Air been drawn to the edition of the Melbourne 'Truth' of 14th October last in which it was stated categorically that records arc kept of the costs incurred by all flights of VIP aircraft, including details of the persons who travel in those planes and the amounts of food and drink provided to them? The report also stated that definite figures are available to show that about §60,000 was spent in one year on the transportation by VIP planes of Mr McEwen, the Deputy Prime Minister. Is the report correct? If not, will the Government issue a denial?

- I did not see the article referred to by the honourable senator, although I have heard some mention of it. The fact that the report appeared in that particular newspaper does not necessarily mean that the details given are correct. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate has just informed the Senate, considerable work is being done to meet the request for papers relating to flights by VIP aircraft to be tabled in the Senate. Any information that can be made available lo the Senate will be made available when those papers are tabled.

- Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that on 14th September 1965 the present honourable member for Kennedy promised club facilities to the senior citizens at Cloncurry in Queensland? Can the Minister inform the Parliament when the club facilities will be made available and whether such facilities will be financed by government grant or on a subsidy basis?

- Of course I am not aware that on 14th September 1965, the honourable member for Kennedy- told somebody that club facilities would be provided for senior citizens at Cloncurry. Perhaps the honourable senator is confusing the promise that the Government made to provide more money for aged persons homes under legislation which the Opposition has so far prevented the Senate from passing.

- I preface my question to the Minister for Repatriation by referring to his recent visit to the Artificial Limb and Appliance Centre at Adelaide. Can the Minister give an indication of the progress on the Centre and when it is likely to be completed? Will the range of appliances to be made there be an extension of those already being produced elsewhere? My next query refers to a question that I have asked earlier of the Minister. Will the new Centre be used for training courses for people undertaking the manufacture of artificial limbs and appliances? Can the Minister give any figures showing the quantity of appliances and artificial limbs that are likely to be produced at the Centre and the number of persons who will be employed there?

- It is true that I took advantage of an opportunity on Monday last to visit the almost completed repatriation Artificial Limb and Appliance Centre at Adelaide. The Centre will cost about $140,000. It will be the most modern artificial limb factory in Australia. Until now the artificial limb factory at Hollywood, in Western Australia, has been the outstanding centre of its kind, but I am quite convinced that the new Centre at Adelaide will be more modern and even better than the Hollywood centre. As to training courses, this will depend on whether the people who need training will be available in Adelaide. Otherwise I would imagine that these people would be trained in the artificial limb factories in the States where they reside. Last year the artificial limb factory in Adelaide supplied 10S legs, 738 articles of surgical footwear and 91 items of adapted footwear. Other surgical 2,605 repairs were effected. It might be of interest to honourable senators to know that the total output of the repatriation artificial limb factories last year was 18,042 items, appliances totalling 809 were supplied and

-.! direct a further question to the Minister representing the Minister for Air. Has the Minister's attention been drawn also to another article which appeared in Melbourne Truth' of 1.4th October last in which it was claimed that while public relations officers of the Royal Australian Air Force and the Department of External Affairs are transported to and from Vietnam by luxury jet aircraft, wounded servicemen being brought back from Vietnam travel in noisy, slow Lockheed Hercules transport aircraft? Following those questions, one of our top medical men, who, 1 think, was an Army officer, accompanied some of our wounded servicemen in one of these Hercules aircraft. As a result of this trip, he formed the opinion that the aircraft now being used are the best types for the purpose.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - No one will agree with him.

- It is not a matter of whether the honourable senator agrees with him. There are not very many people who agree with the honourable senator. The officer to whom I refer would not be holding the position he does unless he was a very highly qualified man. 1 would not imagine that Senator Turnbull has had the opportunity of travelling with these wounded servicemen. talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - No. They can get a VIP aircraft any day.

- I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Transport. Has the Bureau of Roads yet obtained all the staff required for its effective operation? If not, what staff is still required? What is the Bureau doing to obtain the required staff/ When can the Senate expect a report on the activities and findings of this important Bureau?

- I cannot say precisely when the Senate will receive a report, but I can undertake to get a prompt answer to the other questions asked by the honourable senator. Therefore, 1 ask that the question be put on notice. I shall then endeavour to expedite a reply for him.

- I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation whether he can give me any up to date information regarding the proposed airport passenger surcharge mentioned in the Budget. Has the Minister been made cognisant of the views of the councils of rural towns and cities, and of individuals who, in country areas, have contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars towards the purchase, establishment and upkeep of their local aerodromes? Will the Minister give the- Senate an assurance that there will be a differentia] in the charge to be made for passengers flying into and out of country airports?

- Quite clearly, I could not give the assurance for which the honourable senator asks because his question is directed to the Minister for Civil Aviation. I can say, generally, however, that the details of the scheme for passenger service charges are still being worked out and will be considered by the Government when they have been finalised. However, T will make investigations into the matter.

talk.start.para: - This is my final question regarding VIP aircraft. It is directed to the Leader of the Government while the matter T am about to raise is fresh in his memory and he will not have to send for the papers. For the general edification of the very interested public will he explain the reason for which he used a VIP plane to travel to Launceston and Burnie? This would be as good an example as any of the use of such aircraft. What was the purpose of the Minister's trip? How many were in the crew? How many passengers travelled with him? What was the designation of each passenger? At what time did he leave Melbourne and at what time did he leave Burnie?
- And what did he eat and drink?

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - No. I know that loyal Ministers eat only pies and sausage rolls.

- I shall bc delighted to supply the information for which the honourable senator has asked on the understanding that I am speaking to the very best of my recollection. I used the plane concerned to attend the Launceston Show, having been invited to be a member of the official party for the opening ceremony: Unfortunately I missed out getting on to the official stand because I was having lunch at the time. That was the purpose of the first engagement. The second engagement was a meeting being held in Burnie. It was not a political meeting or a meeting ot any political party. It was a joint meeting of groups of people who were interested in State schools, in independent schools and in education generally to discuss education and also employment opportunities. I was invited to attend the meeting. This is a continuing organisation, and I gather that at its next meeting it will be addressed by Mr Neilson, the Minister for Education in Tasmania. The meeting that 1 attended was a public meeting. I think, of some public importance.

speech.para: I did not leave Melbourne. I left Canberra at approximately 10.30 a.m. Canberra time. 1 arrived in Launceston, to go to the Show, at approximately 12.30 p.m. Tasmanian time, which is now different from Eastern Standard Time. I then drove to Burnie for the meeting to which I have referred, lt finished at about 10.30 or 10.45 p.m. Tasmanian time. I left at about 11.30 p.m. Tasmanian time, saved an hour on the way back, and arrived back at about midnight. I. was able to be in my office first thing, or relatively first thing - 1 think it was about 10 o'clock - the next morning. If I had not used this aircraft, either I would have been unable to attend those engagements or 1 would have had to leave Canberra on the Wednesday morning and 1 would have arrived back late on the Friday afternoon.

asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.label: t.
item.para: Has the Minister's attention been directed to a report of a recent statement by the Victorian Premier, Sir Henry Bolte, calling the Commonwealth Government's hospital benefits scheme for pensioners 'a racket and a confidence trick, costing the State of Victoria $19m a year' - representing the difference between the cost of tr eating pensioners and the $5 a day provided by the Commonwealth?
Has the Government any plans to deal with ihis situation, or does it expect the States to increase hospital fees generally?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: 1 and 2. My attention has been drawn to statements by the Premier of Victoria relating to the present arrangements under which the Commonwealth pays $5 a day towards the cost of providing free treatment in public wards of public hospitals for pensioners. These arrangements are neither 'a racket' nor 'a confidence trick'.

speech.para: The Commonwealth has never intended at any stage to meet the full cost of the treatment of pensioners in public wards of public hospitals. The cost of treating this section of the community has traditionally been the responsibility of the State governments. Prior to 1946 pensioners generally received free treatment in public hospitals, entirely at the expense of the State governments.
However, the Commonwealth now assists the States in this regard in order that pensioners may be relieved of the necessity to pay hospital insurance but may still receive free public ward treatment.

Payments by the Commonwealth during the year 1966-67 for the treatment of pensioner patients in public wards of public hospitals amounted to $18.7m of which $4.2m was paid to public hospitals in Victoria.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: Has the Government any information on the current incidence of bubonic plague in Vietnam?

Has the Minister seen a statement of Dr Dunwoody, a British doctor and member of Parliament, who, on returning from Vietnam about 3 months ago, was reported as describing the situation then existing as a massive problem and as claiming that between 10,000 and 20,000 Vietnamese were suffering from the plague and that the plague had been detected recently in America in people returning from Vietnam?
Will the Government thoroughly investigate this matter?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply:

item.para: Information is regularly received by my Department from the World Health Organisation regarding the incidence of quarantinable diseases throughout the world. During the period 1st January to the beginning of August this year there were 615 cases of plague, including 30 deaths, notified in respect of the Republic of Vietnam. There were also 4,084 suspected cases of plague, including 158 deaths. 2 and 3. Neither I nor the officers of my Department have yet seen this statement However, inquiries are being made and the statement will be studied when it is received. I should mention that all persons arriving in Australia from overseas are subjected to quarantine screening for disease, including plague. In addition, strict measures are taken to prevent the entry of plague with rats and other animal vectors. These measures have proved to be highly effective over many years, but I can assure the honourable senator that quarantine procedures are under constant review in the light of changing circumstances and the incidence of diseases, including plague, in other countries.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister rep resenting the Minister for Health,' upon notice:

quote.para: In view of the fact that hundreds of people in Australia use surgical appliances after undergoing colostomy operations, will the Minister give consideration to the free issue of these appliances under the national health scheme?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply:

quote.para: As a matter of Government policy, surgical aids are not at present issued under the national health scheme. However, the Commonwealth provides considerable assistance to patients who have undergone colostomy operations by supplying as pharmaceutical benefits a range of sprays, creams, solutions, powder and surgical cement which these patients are required to use constantly for their conditions. talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice:

item.para: What is the area of land in the Northern Territory which has been leased by the Tipperary Land Corporation?
What are the details of the cost and term of the lease?
Does the establishment of Tipperary Station entail the complete destruction of habitat utilised to the full by grey wallabies and buffaloes?
What compensation is this American corporation making to offset this gigantic fauna ravishment?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Territories has now supplied the following answer:

item.para: The Tipperary Land Corporation acquired by private purchase Pastoral Lease No. 562 (Tipperary Station). This has an area of 3,560 square miles. 2.The lease was renewed for 50 years from 1st July 1960 at a Crown rental of $2,136 per annum. The rental is based on a valuation of the lease as pastoral lands and is re-appraised every 10 years. Recent amendments to the Northern Territory Crown Lands Ordinance require that lands within a pastoral lease developed for agricultural purposes be valued and re-appraised as agricultural lands. Pastoral Lease No. 562 will be reappraised on 1st July 1970. 3 and 4. Tipperary Station was established about 1920. The proposed development of part of the lease by the new owners is in line with trends' throughout Australia to put suitable rural lands to more productive use. The dominant fauna of the area is the agile wallaby. Past experience has shown that clearing and sowing of crops and pastures encourages the increase of this species. Tipperary is not the preferred habitat of the buffalo and only a few are found in this area. Production of cattle will still be the main activity over most of the area which will remain uncleared.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice:

item.para: What are the details of the ownership of a fishing vessel known as the 'Papuan Prince' which is reported to be registered in New Guinea and to fly the Australian flag?
Has such a vessel the approval' of the Department of Territories in carrying a crew mainly composed of Japanese?

talk.start.para: - The Minister has now supplied thefollowing answers:

item.para: The vessel 'Papuan Prince' is owned by the South Sea Fishing CompanyPty Ltd, a company registered in the Territory of Papua and New Guinea with its registered office at Port Moresby. The company purchased the vessel from Japan.

The South Sea Fishing Company Pty Ltd has the approval of the Minister for Territories for operation in New Guinea waters subject to the majority of capital being held and continuing to be held by Australian or Papuan or New Guinean investors. The first year's operations were to be exploratory in nature using a factory ship - the 'Papuan Prince' - with a predominantly Japanese crew. Detailed proposals for the development of the operation, in the light of the exploratory operation, are to be submitted to the Minister for Territories within 12 months from the beginning of the exploratory operation in May 1967. The original proposals submitted by the company envisaged a substantial employment of indigenous personnel by the company in any extension of operations beyond the exploratory stage.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, upon notice:

item.para: How many applications for naturalisation were refused in each year since 1960?
How many intending migrants were refused visas in each year since 1960?
How many intending migrants were refused entry permits in each year since 1960?
How many Australian citizens were refused passports in each year since 1960?
Were applicants in any of these categories given the reasons for such refusals; if so, in which categories?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Immigration has supplied the following reply to the honourable senator's questions:

item.para: With visa applications arising throughout the world on an increasing basis, it is not practicable to maintain the detailed statistics which would be required to give a specific reply to this question. However, experience in the major source countries in Europe indicates that of every 100 applicants who undertake the necessary checks to determine whether they can meet normal entry requirements, approximately 90 are granted entry visas.

All persons entering Australia, if they are immigrants within the meaning of the Migration Act - including persons entering for temporary stay - receive entry permits on arrival, or they become prohibited immigrants upon entry. The operation of the visa system results in very few refusals of entry permits at point of arrival in Australia and these have usually been persons such as stowaways who lack authority to enter. Entry permits are also issued as extensions of temporary entry permits, or to confer resident status upon temporary entrants eligible for that status. Statistics of refusals have not been maintained.
Statistics of refusals of Australian passports have not been kept. Refusals are extremely rare, however.
When an application for naturalisation is refused or deferred on the grounds that the applicant:

item.label: (a)
item.para: has not an adequate knowledge of English or of the responsibilities and privileges of citizenship, or

item.label: (b)
item.para: is unable to meet requirements as to residence, - it is the practice to give the reasons to the applicant, but not when refusal or deferment is based on other grounds. Statistics of refusals and deferments under (a) and (b) are as follows:

speech.para: Where a visa or entry permit is refused, it is not normal practice to give the reasons for the decision.

The character and political background of applicants for passports are not made the subject of inquiry and are not a basis for decision of applications as a general rule. In a few cases passports have been refused to persons who were fugitives from justice, or who had used previous passports for repeated criminal activities overseas, or who were known to contemplate activities abroad of a violent nature directed against the peace, order or good government of another country. These persons refused passports have either been informed of the reasons or have been aware of them.

talk.start.para: - Order! I wish to draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of members of the British delegation of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, led by the Right Honourable Lord Stow Hill, Queen's Counsel. On behalf of honourable senators I extend to them a cordial welcome.

speech.para: Honourable Senators ; Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: - I have received from Senator Tangney an intimation that she desires to move the adjournment of the Senate for the purpose of discussing a definite matter of public importance, namely:

quote.para: The Government's failure to honour its international obligations and to take all possible legislative and administrative steps towards achieving equal pay for men and women for work of equal value.

speech.para: Is the proposed motion supported? (More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places) -

talk.start.para: - 1 formally move:

quote.para: The the Senate. ;ii ils rising, adjourn till tomorrow at 9 a.m.

speech.para: I believe that it is particularly appropriate to bring this proposal before the Senate today because this week is being celebrated throughout Australia as National Equal Pay Week. There may be some misconception in the minds of a lot of people as to what is really meant by the term 'equal pay'. We have heard it said that it means equal pay for the sexes. That is not so. It means equal remuneration for work of equal value, irrespective of the sex of the person who performs that work. We realise that many avenues of employment are peculiarly suitable for women, for which they receive appropriate remuneration. The proposal now before us does not envisage every woman in Australia suddenly receiving at least the male basic wage. That would be a ridiculous suggestion. There is a great need for the Government to face up to the responsibilities which it has to shoulder as a member of international bodies. Over the years we have been very proud of the part that Australia has played in the formation of some of these national bodies and of her being a member of them.

When the United Nations came into being in 1945 the Australian delegation played a very important part in its establishment. We were honoured when Dr Evatt was appointed president of the General Assembly of the United Nations. During the sessions of the organisation which were held in Paris in 1948 the original Universal

Declaration of Human Rights, which was of particular interest to women, was formulated. Since that time, on every occasion when the equality of women in regard to opportunities and remuneration has come up for confirmation before the appropriate bodies the Australian delegates have either voted against the proposal or have abstained from voting. Today we have the startling fact that forty-five nations in the world have adopted the principles of the United Nations charter and of the International Labour Organisation conventions but Australia has not done so. We regard some of these nations as backward countries, and to some we are giving economic aid. We regard ourselves as being a very advanced nation, as enjoying a very high standard of living and as being blessed very prolifically by nature; yet we just do not measure up to our responsibilities as a member of these international organisations.

In order that the Senate may understand more fully what is actually meant by the proposal we are discussing. I refer to the fact that earlier this year the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations submitted to the General Assembly the text of a draft declaration relating to the elimination of discrimination against women. I would like to read extracts from this resolution, which was drafted only in May of this year. The preamble reads:

quote.para: The General Assembly,

Considering that the peoples of the United Nations have, in the Charter, reaffirmed their faith in fundamental human rights, in the dignity and worth of the human person and in the equal rights of men and women.

Considering that the Universal Declaration of Human Rights asserts the principle of nondiscrimination and proclaims that all human beings arc born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind, including any distinction as to sex.

Taking into account the resolutions, declarations, conventions and recommendations of the United Nations and the specialised agencies designed to eliminate all forms of discrimination and to promote equal rights for men and women.

Concerned that, despite the Charter, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other instruments of the United Nations and the specialised agencies and despite the progress made in the matter of equality of rights, there continues to exist considerable discrimination against women,

Considering that discrimination against women is incompatible with human dignity, and with the welfare of the family and of society, prevents their participation, on equal terms with men, in the political, social, economic and cultural life of their countries, and is an obstacle to the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of their countries and of humanity,
Convinced that the full and complete development of a country, the welfare of the world, and the cause of peace require the maximum participation of women as well as men in all fields,
Considering that it is necessary to ensure the universal recognition in law and in fact of the principle of equality of men and women,
Solemnly proclaims this Declaration:

speech.para: I do not intend to read all this draft declaration. 1 shall read only the articles that are relevant to the matter before the Senate this afternoon.

talk.start.para: - What is the date of the draft declaration?
- It is dated 29th May 1967. Article I reads:

quote.para: Discrimination based on sex, denying or limiting as it does equal rights between men and women, is fundamentally unjust and constitutes an offence against human dignity.

speech.para: In part, Article 2 reads:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The principle of equality of rights shall be embodied in the constitution or equivalent law of each country;

item.label: (b)
item.para: The international instruments of the United Nations and the specialised agencies relating to the elimination of discrimination against women shall be ratified and fully implemented as soon as practicable.

speech.para: Article 10 seeks to accord to women:

quote.para: The right to equal remuneration with men and to equality of treatment in respect of work of equal value.

speech.para: The same Article goes on to state that in order to prevent discrimination against women, these proposals should be ratified by all the governments which have signed the various charters and which are constituent members of the United Nations. Only yesterday, in another place, there was given an answer to a question upon notice seeking to ascertain how the Australian delegation would vote now that the matter is to come before the United Nations General Assembly once more. The Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt), in his reply, stated:

quote.para: Australia is nol currently a member of the Economic and Social Council which subsequently adopted the same text.

speech.para: I have just, read part of that text. The answer given by the right honourable gentleman went on:

quote.para: The current (22nd) session of the General Assembly has not yet given consideration to the draft declaration and any amendments to it

speech.para: That being so, I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gorton) whether the Government has considered this matter and whether it has given any instructions to its delegates at the United Nations now that it is known that the matter is specifically to be raised during the present session of the General Assembly.

It has always been the proud boast of supporters of this Government and of all in this Parliament that Australia has adhered to its international obligations. Even when the parties represented in the Parliament have differed over some of those obligations the government of the day has stood by its treaty obligations and in this has received the loyal support of the party or parties in opposition, lt is incumbent on the present Government to support the declarations that have been made by the United Nations through various instrumentalities and also by the International Labour Organisation if we are to hold up our heads as citizens of one of the nations that really honours its obligations. True, this declaration has not yet been ratified by the United Kingdom, Canada, the United States of America or New Zealand, in addition to Australia. But it has been ratified by forty-five other countries. The number might have increased since I was given that figure. The United Kingdom, for instance, does give equality to women employed in its government work force. So does the United States of America. I happened to be in the United States in 1964 when the United States Government, had just brought out its report on the status of women in that country. It had appointed a special committee to deal with the position of women generally, with the disabilities or otherwise that they suffered - legally, constitutionally, politically, economically and in any other way.

talk.start.para: - What are the fortyfive nations sponsoring the draft agreement?

- They include Algeria, Albania, the Argentine, Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Bulgaria, Byelo-Russia, China, Costa Rica, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Dominican Republic, Equador, Gabon, Guatemala, Federal Republic of

speech.para: Germany, France, Haiti, Honduras, Hungary, Iceland, India, Indonesia, Italy, Ivory Coast, Libya, Malagassy Republic, Mexico, Norway, Panama, Peru, Philippines, Poland, Romania, Senegal, Sweden, Syrian Arab Republic, Ukraine, United Arab Republic - Egypt, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Yugoslavia. At the Forty-second Session of the International Labour Organisation, Australia adopted the convention and recommendation concerning discrimination. However the Australian Government delegates abstained from voting in connection with the convention, but supported adoption of the recommendation after the convention had been approved. During the past 15 or 16 years we have seen the same shilly-shallying on the part of Government representatives at these conferences. They agree in principle but when it comes to a vote they walk out or vote against the proposal. Of course, I have seen the same thing happen in the Senate. The reason why I have brought the matter up is that t happen to be one of the few women in this community who, in the employment that they follow, enjoy the right of equal pay. I doubt whether any male honourable senator would take it very kindly if women senators were paid less than he was.

talk.start.para: - What about the equal value part of it?
- Male senators would not for one moment dare to suggest that any woman in this Senate does not give service of equal value. I do not think that even Senator Cormack would dare to come at that.
- I am trying to get the formula to apply.

- As a matter of fact, if work were paid at its valuation it might be quite a different story. I am not pointing the bone at anyone. Senator Cormack had better be a bit careful because he does not know what might happen if he pursued that line. Before I entered the Senate I happened to be a teacher. In that profession women were discriminated against although we had done exactly the same course of training and had exactly the same qualifications as, and sometimes' much higher qualifications than, our male colleagues had. When they were sick we were called upon to do their jobs. During the war I had to take control of a football team. All I could do was to take the members of the team down to the playing field, count them as they went on, let them go for their lives and count them as they came off, and if the number was the same everything was all right. That was part of having to do a man's job in many fields in which we were not trained or capable.

speech.para: But where women are capable of doing a job and where the result of their labour is equal in value, they should not be penalised and made to become a lower rate work force. Some mcn oppose this principle because they are afraid for their jobs. They say that they are saving up to get homes and to look after families when they come along and so forth, which is very good. But I think that in these days of equality of education each year more women are entering more fields which were hitherto primarily open only to men. Earlier in the century very few vocations were open to women. They could become seamstresses. Their industry has always been a cradle of sweated labour. Many years ago, after my father was injured in an accident - this was before the days of workers' compensation - my mother was forced to do white sewing for a big firm in Perth. I never enter the premises of that firm. She had to make pillow slip and pillow cases and was paid 3d a dozen. If the articles had frills around them she was paid 5d a dozen. Out of that payment she would have to supply her own tapes and cottons. Those were the conditions from which women have been rescued. Women could become shop assistants. What happened during the depression? They were employed as shop assistants only during the busy hours of trading. They were hired to work between 11 a.m. and 2 p.m. and were paid only hourly rates - a couple of shillings an hour. This method was used to avoid employing them for a full week.

Female doctors are not found in such great numbers as their male counterparts. Female doctors are not given opportunities equal to those given to male doctors and few are found in the top ranks of their profession. Women doctors are employed in the Commonwealth Public Service. They have excellent academic records and they treat patients in exactly the same way as do male doctors. They are employed in repatriation hospitals, but because they are engaged in the Public Service they receive a lower rate of salary than do male repatriation doctors.

When I was in Los Angeles I met Mrs Wilson, an Australian Trade Commissioner in the United States. She is doing a very fine job for Australia but she is employed at a lower rate of pay than are male trade commissioners. I cannot see how this is just. It is not just. We must educate the community to realise that equal payment for work of equal value is the just entitlement of women and that men as well as women should strive for its introduction. At times men are afraid to give women equal pay because they believe they might lose their jobs. This has been proved to be wrong. A firm in Perth which conducts a chain of stores - I will not name it because I do not wish to give it a free advertisement; it is well known to everybody in Western Australia - brought in equal pay for women a little over 12 months ago. A great deal of criticism came from some sources. Some people thought that the stores would not pay their way, but they have shown increased turnover and increased profits. This has resulted not only from the extra work that the women employees are willing to do because they are getting just pay, but also from the recognition of the community generally of what the stores have done in bringing in equal pay for women. I am hoping that other firms will follow the lead.

The Commonwealth Government has said through its Ministers in the Senate when we have raised this matter before that it is a matter for the courts. Government supporters say: 'We cannot interfere with the courts', and so on. But the Government could take the lead in respect of its own employees. It has entered the field of wage fixation. A start could be made with the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority, lt could bring about not only equal pay but also equal conditions of employment for women. It could lay down conditions which would have to be fulfilled, as it has done in the past. But the Government does not wish to provide equal pay and equal conditions for women. It takes the easy way out and uses the excuse: 'Leave it to the various tribunals'. If the Government were to introduce equal pay for its female employees it could have a great effect throughout the whole community.

talk.start.para: - That is quite right. I hope the honourable senator has made some calculation of the cost.

- 1 am not very good at figures. The honourable senator is better at that than I am. In any case that is no longer a valid argument. But let me relate the experience of New South Wales. Over the years, that State has been introducing equal pay for some of its public servants such as teachers. People said that this was not practicable; that it would put New South Wales at a great disadvantage as compared with the other States. But when the 40-hour week was introduced, it was argued that the economy of New South Wales would ^suffer greatly in comparison with the economies of all the other States. We were told that New South Wales just could not afford the 40-hour week. But what happened? Not only did the economy of New South Wales not suffer but the example set by that State was followed by every other State, and by the Commonwealth itself.

speech.para: I understand that the Queensland Government has made a start towards equal pay for its employees, especially teachers, although I am not quite certain of the position. Senator Morris should be able to put me right on that. Not only has the South Australian Government been granting equal pay to its teachers over the years but last week, or the week before, it brought down legislation for the inclusion of the equal pay provision in the awards of various branches of industry in that State. In Tasmania, the Lower House passed similar legislation, but it was defeated in the Upper House. Otherwise, the principle would have been in operation there also. I regret to say that, of all the States I think Western Australia is the only one that has not made some attempt to deal with the problem.

This is not a problem which affects only the women of the community; it affects the community generally. Today, more girls are remaining at school to go on to universities. More are being educated in co-educational establishments. They are being educated in the sciences, the arts and so on. They have to sit for the same examinations and meet the same requirements as the males. Fresh vistas should be open to them because of this education. In my view, this is one of the most important questions of the day. Let me conclude my remarks by referring to a statement made by the late President Kennedy, who was a champion of this cause of equal opportunities and remuneration for women. When speaking on the establishment of the President's Commission on the Status of Women, he said:

quote.para: Women have basic rights which should be respected and fostered as part of our Nation's commitment to human dignity, freedom and democracy. It is appropriate ... to set forth before the world the story of women's progress in a free, democratic society, to review recent accomplishments, and to acknowledge frankly the further steps that must be taken.

This is a task for the entire nation. lt is my hope that the Commission's report will indicate what remains to be done to demolish prejudices and outmoded customs which act as barriers to the full partnership of women in our democracy. The Commission will welcome recommendations from all groups on this crucial matter. Progress wilt require the co-operation of the whole community.

speech.para: What he had to say about America is equally applicable to Australia today. ( hope that as a first step towards granting women equal pay for equal work in the Commonwealth Public Service the Government will set up a commission. I hope too that it will not be content with merely establishing a fact finding commission but that the commission's report will be followed by action similar to that taken in America after the late President Kennedy's Commission submitted its report. I might remind the Senate also of what another great feminist, Mrs Eleanor Roosevelt, said. Her reply to those who, although they agreed with the principle of equal pay for equal work, argued that the time was not yet: opportune and counselled waiting until tomorrow was: 'Tomorrow is now.'

talk.start.para: - The terms of the motion which is before us say that we should adjourn to a particular time because firstly, of the Government's failure to honour its international obligations in connection with, equal pay for work of equal value. There is absolutely no foundation whatever for any charge that the Commonwealth is dishonouring any international obligations into which it has entered with relation to this matter.

speech.para: I think we should be perfectly clear as to what has been done in this field. The International Labour Organisation had before it a motion which urged that the principle of equal pay for equal work should be adopted by the countries which were members of the Organisation. The Australian delegation voted more than once in favour of the adoption of the proposal that the principle of equal pay for equal work should be accepted. But the motion before the International Labour Organisation did not finish by saying: 'The principle of equal pay for equal work should be adopted'; it went on to say: 'The implementation of that principle in each component country of the Organisation should be according to the wage fixing methods in operation in each country at the time'. There was no suggestion that any government should accept and immediately implement a principle which had been accepted. The position was that the normal processes in operation in a country should be followed to see that equal pay for equal work was introduced in that country.

talk.start.para: - But that was 17 years ago.
- Quite, but thai being the true story of what was accepted there is no basis whatever for a claim that this Government has dishonoured any international obligation.
- But this Government has not endorsed it.

- There was no requirement in the proposal before (he International Labour Organisation that a government should argue a case before the wage fixing tribunal in any country, particularly in a country such as Australia. We voted for the principle.
- But the other countries have endorsed it.

- Other countries have voted for it. I do nol know what the honourable senator means by 'endorsed it'. 1 would be just as surprised as I think Senator Tangney would be if wc ever discovered that throughout the length and breadth of Brazil or Indonesia women were paid the same rates as were mcn. I think we all know that in fact that does not happen.
- There is equal pay in Indonesia.

- I accept the fact that the honourable senator has made that statement, but without wishing to accuse him of knowingly saying something that is incorrect, I will not accept it as an accurate statement. That brings us to the situation of using the usual wage fixing processes in operation in a country to endeavour to attain the principle which the Commonwealth Government voted for and endorsed. What is the usual way in which wage fixing processes in this country occur?
- Has the Minister heard of conciliation?

- Yes. The usual way in which these things occur is by an application to a conciliation or arbitration commissioner. My mind goes back to 1949-50 because, to the best of my knowledge, that was the last occasion on which the trade union movement, which one would normally expect to bring cases before the arbitration court for decision, made an application to the court for equal pay for equal work. I know of no application since made. On that occasion - so long ago, I admit - the court threw out the application on the grounds that the male basic wage in Australia provided for a man, his wife and family, and that if there were a desire to alter that concept, which may or may not bc in operation now but was in operation then, there should be an approach to the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. No such approaches were made. Perhaps some senator on the Opposition side will be able to tell us why no such approaches were made by the trade union movement as a whole or by any single part of it. There may have been an application by some part of it - 1 do not know of any such application - but certainly there was no application by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. So the normal processes of wage fixing in operation in this country were not availed of by those who might most be interested to seek to avail themselves of them.

speech.para: However, although that did not happen the Government gave quite tangible indications of its general approach to this matter and its adherence to the kind of policies that Senator Tangney quoted as coming from the late President Kennedy. I remind the Senate that we pay to men and women the same margin for skill, that margin being a payment over and above the basic payment which is supposed to provide for a man, his wife and family.

talk.start.para: - But not the base rate.

- The honourable senator is saying something quite different from what 1 am saying. I am pointing out the steps that have been taken to show the Government's acceptance of the principle of equal pay for equal work, and what has been clone to put that acceptance clearly before the people. I cite another instance of this Government's avoidance of discrimination in female employment. The honourable senator's mind will at once go back to the recent occasion when wc removed the long-standing bar on the employment of married women in the Public Service. So two great steps forward have been taken in the situation of females employed by the Commonwealth. I do not think Senator Tangney could claim that anything I have said so far is in any way really subject to dissention or rebuttal.

speech.para: We have all heard the statement: 'All right, certainly in this country there is an arbitration court and there are conciliation commissioners which are the normal tribunals to alter wages, and we admit there have not been any applications to those tribunals to try to vary the female basic wage, but why does not the Commonwealth Government, regardless of the normal wage fixing methods in Australia, take unilateral action through its own Public Service to provide an equal base rate?' There arc organisations in the Commonwealth Public Service culminating in the High Council of Commonwealth Public Service Organisations. 1 know of no application that that body has yet made.

talk.start.para: - lt has tried to sec the Prime Minister.
- I know of no application along those lines that that body has yet made to the tribunal dealing with Public Service salaries. Does the honourable senator know of one?
- 1 thought I did but perhaps 1 had belter check.
- I may be wrong but 1 know of no application to a court.
- It has made direct application to the Government.

- I am speaking of an application to the wage fixing machinery normally in operation in Australia. I think the Public Service has its own wage fixing tribunal. I know of no application to it. I mention that in passing.
- That body is nol uninterested in this problem.

- 1 do not know whether it is interested or uninterested, lt does not appear to have shown much interest in taking action to get for its members equal pay for equal work. That is the only point I am making.
- It has done that' but not on the level the Minister wants.
- Not on the level of the normal wage fixing machinery in a country, which is the method the ILO has laid down to be used.
- The court has two fields, conciliation and arbitration.

- Of course. Does the honourable senator know of any application to the conciliation part of it? I do not. Does he know of any application to the arbitration part of it? I do not. I am merely seeking to make the point, which 1 think the interjections tend to underline, that although members of the High Council have said that they would like equal pay for equal work, no action to that end has been taken through the processes through which action is normally taken by unions and councils. I state that by the way.

speech.para: It has been suggested that in spite of that lack of action the Commonwealth should itself unilaterally make a decision in regard to its own employees. I do not draw conclusions from this point at this moment, but I suggest that honourable senators might turn their minds to whether it is not true that action in respect of the Commonwealth Public Service would have far wider effects than the smaller action that has been taken by State governments such as the New South Wales Government in respect of limited parts of their public services. Would not such action have a very strong effect on all the State governments which have partly-

talk.start.para: - It would be wonderful.
- That is what the honourable senator wants, is it not?
- Yes.

- Would it not go beyond that and have a very great effect, naturally enough, on the whole of the private sector? That is exactly what Senator Tangney says she wants. But would it not have such a very great economic effect on this country - on its internal and external operations - that this matter should be the subject of proper consideration by the highest arbitration tribunal which considers the economic effects on Australia whenever it is hearing an application for increased wages?

speech.para: What is being asked for here is not just for the Commonwealth Government to take some small action concerning only a few people in its own employ. What is being asked for is that the Commonwealth Government should bypass the constituted methods of fixing wages in the light of their economic effect on the country. That is a factor that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission would take into account, as I think all honourable senators will agree, when considering something which is really not a small matter but one of the greatest concern to the Australian economy generally and consequently to Australian employment prospects generally. I have said that I am not drawing conclusions on that point. I am not saying what the economic effects would be; how far we could afford to go; or what steps, if taken, would have an effect-. I am merely saying that, whatever way we look at this matter, the results for Australia's external trade and internal employment would be great, and that therefore this is a proper subject for examination by the Arbitration Commission, to which we refer such matters in all other areas and to which the trade unions refer such matters. We have very largely taken these matters out of politics and left the Arbitration Commission to make its economic judgments on the cases of the protagonists before it. That is something which needs to be very carefully borne in mind when it is suggested that some comparatively light-hearted action should be taken-

talk.start.para: - We do not suggest light-hearted action.

- . . . when it is suggested that action should be taken without a full realisation of the immense responsibilities involved. I believe that the Treasurer (Mr McMahon), when he was Minister for Labour and National Service, stated on behalf of the Government that if a case such as this were brought before the Arbitration Commission by the Australian Council of Trade Unions or some other responsible body the Commonwealth Government would not oppose it in principle. So what is there to prevent the proper utilisation of the wage fixing machinery by the people who are so interested - and properly interested - in this matter? In doing that they would be acting in accordance with the accords that were signed and supported at the International Labour Organisation conferences in Geneva. Those accords state that the implementation of the principle to which we agreed should be carried out in that way in Australia. I do not know what the wage fixing methods applicable in other countries are. But, whatever they are, they are the ones that should be used in the respective countries.
- We want the Commonwealth Government to take the initiative.

- I think I have dealt with that point a little. What the honourable senator is really asking the Government to do is to bypass the arbitration machinery on a matter that has immense and far reaching economic consequences. Such action could be initiated by either the ACTU or a particular union to which some honourable senators opposite belong. I do not know the unions to which they belong, but I am sure that some of them belong to some unions. Why is not action initiated in that way?
- Some unions have taken action. Barmen and barmaids receive equal pay in Western Australia. Women working in timber mills also receive it now.

- That would be the result of action taken before the State conciliation commission. But what we are talking about has Australia-wide application. I speak subject to correction, but I believe that at long last an application for equal pay is now before an Australian wage fixing tribunal. I believe that the Bank Officials Association now has such an application before the Arbitration Commission. I suppose that the decision in that case will have considerable influence on decisions of the Commission in respect of related industries.
- What about the journalists and employees of radio stations?
- Have they an application before a tribunal?
- They already receive equal pay, do they not?

- I am talking about an application that is before the Arbitration Commission at the moment. No doubt the decision on the bank officers' application will have a very considerable effect. If it goes the way the union would like it to go, it should be an encouragement to other employee organisations to apply to have it extended. If it is true that such applications are being made and that some of them are now before the Arbitration Commission - the proper wage fixing machinery - does that not show that this is the proper way and the traditional way for a matter of this kind to be dealt with in Australia?
- What about the professional officers in the Minister's Department?
- Have they an application before a tribunal?
- To what tribunal can they go?
- Is the honourable senator referring to professional officers in the Commonwealth Public Service?
- Yes.

- Is there not a tribunal to which public servants can apply? I believe that there is a Public Service conciliation and arbitration commission. My nomenclature may not be accurate, but undoubtedly there is a tribunal to which professional officers and other public servants can apply for wage variations. If they have not applied for equal pay for equal work, why have they not done so? If they have a case before the tribunal now, then let us leave it to the tribunal and do not let us suggest that we, as members of the Parliament, should take such a far reaching decision, unless honourable senators opposite wish to adopt an attitude which I would not adopt although I understand some of the arguments for it. I refer to the view that we should not have arbitration in Australia because we are taking away from the Parliament and giving to an arbitration tribunal the power to make decisions of great economic moment affecting wage levels and employment and economic matters generally. As I said, I would not adopt that attitude, but it is the only basis on which a proper case could be made out for abandoning the normal wage fixing methods.

speech.para: Let me sum up. There oan be no proper or true accusation of failure to honour international agreements because, whilst we have supported and still support the principle, we have not refused to do anything that we undertook to do. It can be claimed that the Government should take the administrative steps suggested in the second part of the matter of urgency towards providing equal pay for equal work. But I do not think that claim can be sustained in view of the arguments that I have put forward on the immense and far reaching economic effect - something that traditionally is dealt with by our wage fixing machinery, which is still available to deal with it and which has had some cases along these lines brought before it - and in view of the fact that a senior spokesman for the Government has said that an application along these lines would not be opposed in principle. In support of that statement, I point out that in fact the Government has voted for this in principle at conferences of the International Labour Organisation, and that in practice the Government has removed the discrimination of the marriage bar against women and is paying equal pay for equal work in respect of the margin for skill component of wages in the Commonwealth Public Service.

talk.start.para: - The Senate is discussing a matter of urgency raised by Senator Tangney. This is an extremely important matter. The honourable senator has referred to the Government's failure to honour its international obligations and to take all possible legislative and administrative steps towards achieving equal pay for men and women for work of equal value. It is obvious from the speech of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gorton) that the terms of the motion have touched the Government on the raw.

speech.para: What is involved is a double accusation, firstly that the Government has failed to honour its international obligations in this respect and secondly that it has failed to do what it could have done legislatively and administratively to put into effect the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. The Minister has argued that the Government has not been guilty of a breach of international obligation because Australia has never ratified Convention No. 100 of the International Labour Organisation adopted in June 1951, although Australia did subsequently adopt in principle a recommendation approving the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. I concede that Australia has not ratified the Convention. We have in fact a very poor record in ratification of ILO conventions. We have allowed 16 years to pass without ratifying the Convention. We have not followed the example of about thirty other countries. We have not done what countries like Indonesia, India and Japan have done, namely write into our Constitution the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. We lag behind countries which we and the world generally would regard as less advanced in this respect than Australia.

talk.start.para: - Does the honourable senator suggest that this is the cause or the effect?

- It may be a bit of both but the fact is that having voted for the principle, as the Leader of the Government has told us Australia did, it seems to me that Australia undertook certain international obligations, You may say that they are not strictly binding in the international law sense, but as a matter of morality, having committed itself to the principle, and this principle being involved in a recommendation adopted by the ILO, after the ILO Convention was adopted Australia's obligation - 1 am quoting the words of the Convention - is to promote and insofar as is consistent with such methods, ensure the application to all workers of the principle of equal pay for men and women workers for work of equal value.

speech.para: We have witnessed a magnificent example of wriggling by the Leader of the Government on this question. He referred ,to the Government's not opposing the principle, whereas in fact the international obligation is not merely not to oppose the principle but to support it and to support it throughout the range of national activity. That means supporting it wherever it is possible for the Government to take action. In short, Senator Tangney's argument is that there is no limitation of the Commonwealth's power to prescribe salaries for its own officers in the Commonwealth Public Service. So the first thing the Government could do without any legal inhibition or restriction is to apply this principle in the Commonwealth- Public Service. It is of no use talking, as Senator Webster did by way of interjection, about the millions of dollars which the application of this principle would cost. The former Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, in answer to a question on 17th May 1962 from the present Leader of the Opposition in another place, Mr Whitlam, referred to the estimated cost of applying the principle in the Commonwealth Public Service and said:

quote.para: The estimated cost of introducing equal remuneration for men and women for work of equal value, that is, of introducing an equal base rule in the case of those females already receiving equal margins, is -

item.label: (a)
item.para: approximately £1.3m per annum for female employees of the Commonwealth Government employed under the Public Service Act; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: approximately £650,000 per annum for all other civilian female employees of the Commonwealth Government except locally recruited staff employed overseas.

speech.para: So the total cost, as estimated by Sir Robert Menzies in 1962, was a little less than £2m per annum. Since that time 5 years have elapsed and one may take it that the cost now would bc about $5m.

This is really what we are asking the Commonwealth Government to face up to. We are met with the argument that the Commonwealth is not opposed. This attitude of non-opposition has been held by the Commonwealth for more than a decade. In 1958 the present Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt), who was then Minister for Labour and National Service, said that the Commonwealth did not oppose the principle of equal remuneration for men and women for work of equal value, but where have we ever had from this Government or any responsible spokesman for it any indication that it is prepared to support the principle? There is all the difference in the world between non-opposition and support.

Senator Gortonsaid that the Treasurer (Mr McMahon) at some time - I do not recall this having been said - indicated that if an application were made to the industrial tribunals the Commonwealth would not oppose it. What does non-opposition mean in these tribunals? It simply means staying neutral, lt does not mean support. 1 invite any honourable senator on the Government side who rises to take part in the debate to say whether the Commonwealth will support such an application before the industrial tribunals. If the Government is not prepared to go that far it is not doing what it should do as a matter of obligation, legal and moral, because we arc committed to the principle. The Government is not doing what it should as a matter of obligation to promote the principle and to ensure that it is adopted. I do not think any honourable senator opposite can gainsay that proposition. This is more than an industrial matter. It is easy to look at this question as though it were simply an industrial question.

Something much more is involved than a mere industrial question. In Victoria 55 years ago the late Sir Leo Cussen, a judge of the Supreme Court, hearing an appeal from a wages board dealing with an application for equal pay said:

quote.para: This is a matter of such profound political, social and economic importance that it is a matter tor the legislature.

speech.para: Mark you, that was in 1912, but he might have been saying it today. In 1967 in Victoria the teachers' tribunal, which has been asked in recent times to adjudicate on the subject of equal pay - Victoria and Western Australia are the two States in which the principle of equal pay for women teachers has nol been adopted - has said that this matter is much too important to be decided by an industrial tribunal; it is a matter of economic and social policy that has to be decided by the legislature. What is involved here is not simply an industrial question; it is a matter in which Australia is committed internationally to a social judgment about the place of women in society. That is what the argument is really all about. We cannot talk about equality of status for women where we have no equality of remuneration.

To the extent to which the Commonwealth has recently removed barriers to married women working in the Commonwealth Public Service, that move is welcome. It should have happened ages ago. But the equality is incomplete because women are not guaranteed equal pay for work of equal value in the Commonwealth Public Service. One would not expect a woman member of Parliament, whether in this Parliament or in any other, to accept remuneration at less than the rate which is given for other members of Parliament because by so doing she would be accepting a second class status. This is the crux of the matter. It is the kernel of the question in the view we put.

talk.start.para: - But the argument would be equally true that the honourable senator should be down-graded in his rate of remuneration because the work he does is not equal in value to the work that Senator Tangney does.
- I do not think that is really a serious argument.
- It is a serious argument.

- In the way it has been put I do not regard it as such. If we had to satisfy some tribunal as to what the proper remuneration for members of Parliament was I cannot imagine that Senator Cormack or any other honourable senator would want to argue that there should be some difference in salary between female and male members of the legislature. Whether the remuneration is too high or too low I do not know, but certainly there should not be any discrimination between the sexes. As we see it, this is the whole point of the argument.

speech.para: The Commonwealth has not done what it could have done. It should be setting the lead. It should be saying: 'We can grant this equality to our own officers. We do not have to have a hearing before the Arbitrator. We are perfectly able to make the big judgment that is required on a principle which is so important and we can apply it in areas where we have the say.' It is only where there is a disagreement between employer and employee about conditions of employment that the arbitral process is invoked. If agreement can be reached between employer and employee - this has often happened - there is no need for an, arbitrator. As to the general case that might be brought in one industry or in industry generally, this is a matter on which the unions would make up their minds as to how they apply to the industrial tribunals. But so far there has been no indication from the Commonwealth that it will support the argument before the industrial tribunal. All the rest of it is mere talk. It is only talk to speak in the grandiose language, in the exquisite language which conceals meaning, that we get on these questions. It is so much talk to speak about non-opposition. The positive obligation is to take positive steps to promote the principle. We cannot see why it is not possible for the Commonwealth to do this. It can do it and in so doing it will be applying a principle which already has world wide acceptance and which is in the Declaration of Human Rights. It was adopted in express words in the Treaty of Rome constituting the European Economic Community.

All over the world this principle is coming to be regarded as important because it is part of the emancipation of peoples and part of the emancipation of underprivileged groups within each separate country. In some countries it may be people of a subject race; in some countries it is people of a subject sex. We believe in this principle. We would deem it extremely important for a country like Australia which, in many respects, is entitled to claim that it is among the most advanced countries in the world, although it is not one of the largest. We believe that in our own country it is high time the principle was not only talked about but acted upon.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Drake-Brockman - Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

talk.start.para: - This is obviously the political season. Here we are in the Senate today discussing what is said to be a matter of urgency. The question of equal pay for work of equal value, irrespective of the sex of the worker, has been discussed in this chamber on many occasions in the last 10 years. The Parliament is at present hard pressed to get sufficient time in which to examine the huge Budget of expenditure and the Estimates, yet for some political purpose the

speech.para: Australian Labor Party has introduced for discussion a matter of urgency. I wish to protest against the employment of this procedure for what is purely a propagandist purpose. I want to say also that I regard this drum that is being beaten by the Labor Party as purely a propagandist drum. Nobody today holding responsible office in the trade unions, the Parliaments or commerce would deny that work of equal value is entitled to equal remuneration.

talk.start.para: - Except this Government.
- The honourable senator interjects a comment which is unintelligible to me, not only because of what was said but because I did not hear it dearly.
- The honourable senator said that no one would deny it and I am saying that this Government would do so.

- I wanted to offer a purely charitable reason for not understanding the honourable senator's interjection. Passing from that, it is said in this motion that the Senate should adjourn because of the Government's failure to honour its international obligations. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gorton) has dealt with this matter, but to put the record straight I quote the terms of convention No. 100 of the International Labour Organisation conventions which reads:

quote.para: Bach member shall by means appropriate to the methods in operation for determining rates of remuneration promote and, in so far as consistent with such methods, ensure the application to all workers of the principle of equal remuneration for men and women workers for work of equal value.

speech.para: The terms of that ILO convention recognise that in the member countries there are particular methods by which industrial changes are achieved. The obligation of members who signed the convention is to promote this principle by means appropriate to the methods in operation for determining rates of remuneration. It is quite clear that in the Commonwealth sphere the predominant function of the Federal Parliament in industrial matters is confined to legislating for arbitration and conciliation. lt is mere distortion of an irresponsible kind to suggest that the Common wealth Parliament has a direct power to implement this principle by legislation. The ILO convention recognises the propriety of adhering to the appropriate means that the country has constituted to alter rates of remuneration in industry.

The Opposition says that the Government has failed to take all possible legislative and administrative steps towards achieving equal pay for men and women for work of equal value. The main suggestion seems to be that the Commonwealth should introduce this principle blandly in the Public Service. I shall examine that suggestion. The Commonwealth has shown its recognition of the rights of women by taking a very forward step within the last 12 months to remove all the handicaps suffered by married women in relation to employment in our Public Service. We took great care to give to married women by legislative means full status and remuneration in the Public Service. We made provision for the vicissitudes of their sex. The base rate in the Public Service is fixed according to the position and margins are applicable to those positions whether they are held by men or women. 1 suggest that it is irresponsible - indeed it borders on the ridiculous - to suggest that the Federal Government and the Federal Parliament should apply to members of the Public Service a principle of such wide implication as that contained in the proposal that we are discussing. In the course of my speech I shall show that the number of Public Service personnel is altogether too great and that the growth should be arrested.

In my opinion it would be quite inappropriate for the Federal Parliament to select the Public Service as the privileged section of workers in Australia to whom this principle should apply. The implications of this principle are so wide, not merely in the industrial field but also in the social field, that it would be quite wrong to apply it to the Public Service. It is said that members of the Australian Labor Party are propagandists for removing all discrimination between the sexes. We have had to consider the conjugal state of workers. Married, workers were found to be at a disadvantage when we introduced child endowment. As 1 have pointed out, the restriction on the employment of married women in tha Public Service was remedied last year..

So that we may understand the degree to which females are employed in the work force, I propose to refer to some figures which are applicable to June 1961. They are the latest that I have available. They show that females represented 25.1% of the total Australian work force and that males represented 74.9%. The females were classified into the following categories:

There are some other interesting details that I shall give. I refer to those industries in which the percentage of the female work force is above 20%. They are as follows: Manufacturing industries, 23.9%; commercial industries, 22.2%; and public authority and professional, 24.7%. I suggest to the Parliament that the powers that the Federal Parliament has conferred upon the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission show that it is recognised that the Commission has the chief and predominant responsibility for moulding the development of industrial conditions - so much so that in the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act the following matter was specifically included in the definition of the term 'industrial matters': any claim that the same wage shall be paid to persons of either sex performing the same work or producing the same return of profit or value to their employer.

This Parliament recognised that one of the special matters within the jurisdiction and authority of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was the determination of whether or not this principle should apply.

In the national wage case of 1967, the Commission, in deciding to substitute for the basic wage plus a margin the concept of a total wage, had this to say about the significance of that principle in relation to the female wage:

quote.para: Although we refer to the total wage, there will for the present be a different total wage for males and females and a number of total wages for many classifications. These result from existing basic wage differentials and from the quite complex history of basic wages, particularly those for females, starting many years ago from a concept of differing needs and responsibilities of men and women. Both basic wages have over the years been adjusted in a variety of ways. We are conscious of these apparent anomalies, but consider it is not practicable to attempt to deal with either at this time.

The community is faced with economic industrial and social challenges arising from the history of female wage fixation. Our adoption of the concept of a total wage has allowed us to take an important step forward in regard to female wages. We have on this occasion deliberately awarded the same increase to adult females and adult males. The recent Clothing Trades decision affirmed the concept of equal margins for adult males and females doing equal work. The extension of that concept to the total wage would involve economic and industrial sequels and calls for thorough investigation and debate in which a policy of gradual implementation could be considered.

speech.para: The process is in the course of evolution. In my view it would be destructive in the extreme for this Parliament to intervene, especially when it is known to the Labor Party that the trade union movement has not resolved its attitude to this question. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gorton) pointed out, a claim for the application of this principle has not been made in an important case or in an important dispute in the federal sphere. To apply this principle as suggested would be a complete intrusion by the Parliament into a matter which is predominantly industrial in nature and which the Arbitration Commission is already developing, as shown by what it stated in the judgment which I have read. In my view it would be mischievous for us to interfere.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Drake-Brockman) Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

talk.start.para: - Mr Deputy President, I suggest that Senator Wright was wrong when he said that the trade union movement is dodging its obligation to go before the arbitration tribunals in this matter.
