- I did not say that. 1 said that it had not resolved its attitude.

- Well, it is the same thing. Today we on this side of the Senate are putting to the Government a plea that it do the right thing in this matter. The High Council of Public Service Organisations and the Australian Council of Salaried and Professional Associations have been saying ever since the Equal Remuneration Convention was adopted in 1951 that there ought to be some move towards its ratification and that this Government should do everything possible to promote it and should act administratively to assent to it. This is what the urgency motion now before the Senate proposes. This is not a political move by any means. As honourable senators will probably remember, this matter has been the subject of an annual campaign both by overall workers and white collar workers for more than 10 years. Over that time, they have been continually urging the Commonwealth Government to apply the principle of equal pay to its own employees. If the Government rests on the difficulty of getting employers within the States that are constituent members of the Australian Federation to agree - a difficulty that it has often mentioned - let it at least promote equal pay among its own employees. The cost would be very small, as Senator Cohen has pointed out. The Government could have adopted equal remuneration for its own employees years ago and in addition it could have promoted a meeting of the State Premiers to consider this matter.

speech.para: In recent years, State legislatures, including that of my own State, have adopted legislation providing for equal pay for equal work because they know that this question, in its proper context, cannot be resolved before the arbitration tribunals. Before those tribunals, Conservative governments and conservative employers, within the legal framework, put arguments designed to impede any move for the adoption of equal pay, just as they resist all proposals for increases in wage levels. Since the adoption of the Equal Remuneration Convention by the International Labour Organisation, equal pay for equal work has been adopted in many industries. Many women are now in exactly the same position as men when they do the same work. In the various professions, many more women have been able to assume very high positions that formerly were exclusive to men and have shown that they are able to do the work equally well. This is the current trend in Australia, and this trend is even stronger overseas. But this Government still rests on the old position that it adopted in 1962.

talk.start.para: - How would the honourable senator make up for the disadvantage to the married man?
- I have only 10 minutes available and I intend to discuss this matter in the way that suits me.
- That is the answer of the old soap box orator.

- No, it is not. Australia is a member of the International Labour Organisation. This Government and the governments of other member countries send representatives to meetings of the Organisation and also promote the attendance of worker and employer delegates. The meetings of the Organisation decide on recommendations and conventions that are designed to raise social standards throughout the world and to prevent the great conflict between the poor nations and the rich ones. This Government, since it takes part in formulating such recommendations and conventions, and thereby in raising standards, ought to make sure that in Australia it takes proper steps to give effect to the recommendations and conventions of the Organisation. This is the test: What has it done to promote the principle of equal pay? I should like the Government ro answer that question. I have spoken on this matter in the Senate since 1962. The position that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gorton) has taken up today is the same one that was adopted in 1962 by the present Treasurer (Mr McMahon), who was then Minister for Labour and National Service. Mr McMahon on that occasion used the same sort of argument as Senator Wright has put today. He stated that the Government is not obliged to do any more than it is doing to implement the Convention. He said that once it has been adopted and we have ratified it, we must use the means appropriate within our own country to implement it. The appropriate means within the Australian community, industrially, do not depend only on court processes and conciliation and bargaining. We can show that in the whole gamut of industrial relations more and more female workers throughout the community are obtaining not just the margin awarded to male workers but the total wage paid to male workers.

speech.para: Each year, when we have raised this matter, the proposition that has been put to us in reply has been: 'Why does not the trade union movement go before the arbitration tribunals?' The answer is short, and I have already given it to the Senate. We know the attitude of this Government and therefore it is of no use for us to go before the arbitration tribunals. Regularly, the Government has warned the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission against wage increases. When we have asked Ministers in this chamber to state whether, before the Commission, the Government would support the principle of equal pay, they have never answered: Yes. it will'. Let the Leader of the Government tell us today that this Government will support this principle as some of the Stale governments are doing. If we received that response, it might be worth while for ACSPA, the High Council of Public Service Organisations, white collar workers in general and the trade union movement as a whole to take a different attitude, for it would be possible then to promote some process in the arbitration tribunals.

I put it to the Senate this afternoon that the Government is merely shelving its responsibilities. It has taken no steps to promote the application of the principle of equal pay within the States. It has merely stood back and watched some State governments applying this principle to their own workers and dealing with all the difficulties of formulating the necessary legislation. This Government could do likewise if it wished to help. The only thing that it has ever done in response to the campaign by the trade union movement over the last 10 years has been to establish a Women's Section in the Department of Labour and National Service. It has refused even to accede to requests made by its own supporters. On a number of occasions, Senator Dame Ivy Wedgwood has asked the Government to establish a women's bureau of the kind that operates in the United States of America, but the Government has refused. As recently as last year, it has reaffirmed that its attitude is that announced in 1962 by the former Minister for Labour and National Service. On that occasion, Mr McMahon said:

quote.para: A recommendation of the ILO carries no more legal obligation than its name implies. The Convention is not in force in Australia as it has not be. n ratified by the Commonwealth. 1 say that any government that supports the principles of an international organisation, as we support the International Labour Organisation, should promote the recommendations and conventions thai have been adopted by that Organisation. This applies to employer delegates as well as to representatives of the Government. In 1964, the Australian Government supported an ILO resolution which was carried by 265 votes to 23 and part of which was in these terms:
Urgently appeals to member States to take all positive steps:

item.label: (a)
item.para: To ratify and implement fully the Equal Remuneration Convention 1951, and Discrimination (Employment and Occupation) Convention 1958; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: To implement in respect of girls and women the provisions of the Vocational Training Recommendation 1962.

speech.para: We on this side of the Senate cannot be truthfully accused of playing politics. We are bringing before the Parliament the urgent need for this Government to honour its obligation to do something to promote the adoption of the principle of equal pay for equal work. Later I shall return to the statement made by Mr McMahon in 1962, which is the basis of the Government's present approach to this question.

As recently as November of last year, in answer to a question asked by Senator Hendrickson, Senator Gorton talked about the means appropriate to the promotion of equal pay. I have pointed out very clearly, I suggest, that the Government has an obligation to promote the adoption ot the principle of equal pay and similar measures. It may find difficulty with certain State governments in getting agreement, as it suggests, but it could at least bring the State Premiers together to discuss the matter. Why should the Government always rest on the subterfuge - and it is only a subterfuge - of saying: 'Why do the unions not go before the arbitration tribunals?' We also hear from honourable senators on the Government side the sort of response that we heard from Senator Cormack today. Mr McMahon adopted much the same approach when he talked about reducing the male rate. In 1962, speaking of the instruments of the ILO, he said:

quote.para: It is to be noted of the instruments, first, that they are silent about the level at which equality is to be established: They would be satisfied by a reduction of the male rate to the female or by bringing the two together at some intermediate point; they would be equally satisfied by raising the female rate to the male.

speech.para: What sort of backward nonsense is this, in a world in which this Government is urging more females to go into industry? We find Ministers on important occasions urging women to enter the work force and giving figures lo show the increase of the employment of females in industry. But they refuse to give women wage justice. We now have a situation in which women are working beside men, doing exactly the same work and receiving less pay. This is wrong. Senator Wright has talked about figures. Mr McMahon has been before meetings of employers and advocated that they should adjust their rosters and do everything else that they could do to increase the number of women employed in industry. The percentage of women entering industry is becoming greater. The intake is accelerating. Although in the current year the number of civilian employees received into the work force has in fact dropped and is the lowest intake since 1962, the increase in the intake of female workers is marked. I should like to refer to a document entitled Women in the Work Force', issued by the Department of Labour and National Service in July 1967. The Department gives figures to show the effect of the Government's efforts to persuade employers to make adjustments in order to bring more females into industry. At page 30 fi the document the Department states:

quote.para: Females constituted nearly 40% of the increase in the civilian work force between 1954 and 1966. In the same period the female work force increased at a higher average annual rate than the male in both private and government sectors. The higher rate of female increase is particularly noticeable since 1961.

A table on page 7 of the document shows that between 1947 and 1961 the total population increased by 38.6% and the work force increased by 32.2%. The increase in the female population was 37.4% but the increase in the female work force was 47.7%. Here we see evidence of the situation that I have mentioned previously. Various Ministers have gone to meetings of employers and meetings of women and urged that there be more attraction within industry for women workers. We know that every conference of the International Labour Organisation is for the purpose of raising standards of workers. The Government is represented and it takes along representatives of employers and employees, who take part in the deliberations. If the Government faces difficulty in implementing ILO recommendations because of CommonwealthState relations, it can easily bring about consultations with State Premiers to see whether this will assist. I ask the Government to point out where it has taken such action in all these years. Nothing has been done to give effect to this principle. Our action in bringing forward this matter is on behalf of all people in industry. Recently the Australian Council of Trade Unions passed a resolution in this connection. This proposition has been put to the Government regularly by deputations and by other means for many years:

We call on the Commonwealth Government to apply the principle of equal pay to women employees in all Commonwealth Government instrumentalities and services and stress that further representations be made to the Commonwealth Government for the establishment of an Australian Commission on the Status of Women similar to that of the USA and for the setting up of a Women's Bureau within the Department of Labour and National Service.

speech.para: I conclude by pointing out that Senator Dame Ivy Wedgwood herself asked the Government to do this in recent years but the Government refused, saying that the United States Commission on the Status of Women was too wide and there was no need for such an organisation in Australia. All that we have is a fairly limited section of the Department of Labour and National Service which deals only with basic employment questions and not with wider issues, although the Government is encouraging a greater intake of females into the work force at lower rates of pay. The Government is accepting a lower standard for females generally in industry when it can take a part in promoting equal pay for women who do the same work as men.

talk.start.para: - J find myself in agreement with Senator Wright when he claims that these matters of urgency, of which this is the third in about 5 or 6 sitting days, indicate that the Opposition is more concerned with establishing means by which it can assert clements of political propaganda, because a Senate election is around the corner. That is fair comment; I do not think any objection can be taken to it. There is a vast backlog of parliamentary business which it is necessary to get through prior to the lifting of the Senate for the election. I do not quite see how it will be got through. The services of the community have to be sustained by the passing of the Estimates and the Appropriation Bills. Yet in the last 5 or 6 sitting days we have had these matters brought into the Senate on the ground that they are matters of extreme urgency. 1 will not argue that perhaps some are not matters of urgency that require attention but there have been some 6 or 7 weeks in which these matters could have been brought to the attention of the Senate. They are not any more urgent today than they were 6 weeks ago. I think it is quite clear, as Senator Wright claims, that this is an electioneering device.

speech.para: However, having said that, I would like to pay a compliment to Senator Tangney for speaking out, as she has done so often, on behalf of her sex in relation to equality of pay for work of equal value. 1 am sorry that as we get older we do not succeed in attaining that which we set out to do. I refute Senator Bishop's claim that it is a stupid argument to say that equal pay between the sexes must be on the basis which 1 shall make clear. I say without any cynicism at all that if payment were on the basis of results and competence Senator Tangney would be entitled to higher pay than some other members of the Parliament. She introduced into this debate a draft resolution which is at the present moment being trundled through the General Assembly of the United Nations. By interjection I asked her to read out the names of the nations that were sponsoring the draft resolution. The interesting thing is that we find that if is sponsored by the usual collection of ragbag nations inside which there is no device, as far as I have been able to discover, by which the principles of the United Nations and the International Labour Organisation have been in any way put into effect. I have been to Indonesia, Algeria, Gabon and some other African nations, and I have never seen in those nations any attempt to apply equal pay for work of equal value. In fact, the delegates of those nations are attempting to create inside the United Nations means by which they can put pressure on their own domestic political parties or governments. The fact is that the nations that have abstained from acceding to this draft treaty or having very much to do with it are nations that have in their own domestic jurisdictions the means of solving the problem as to whether or not the conventions of the International Labour Oragnisation should be put into effect.

talk.start.para: - Which are the abstaining ones?
- The ones that have not acceded or have nol approved the draft resolution. Senator Tangney read out their names. I cannot recollect them all. Australia is one. The United Kingdom is another.
- And the United States.

- The United States is a third. One cannot use what is happening inside the United Nations, for example, as an argument to sustain the raising in the Senate this afternoon as a matter of urgency the proposal that legislation should be introduced and administrative action taken to establish equal pay for work of equal value, which is the formula of the International Labour Organisation. Senator Wright also said that we have in this country a system by which wage problems can be solved. The issue that is quite clearly demonstrated in the Senate this afternoon is the means by which equal pay for work of equal value should be established in Australia. Because we have an arbitration system Government supporters do not accept the proposition contained in the matter of urgency raised by the Opposition.

speech.para: I do not think 1 am going outside . the bounds of forecasting when I say that not one honourable senator on this side of the chamber does not accept the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. I do not think I am committing any honourable senator on this side when I say that in private discussions as members of Parliament in the corridors and in the party rooms - it is certainly true so far as I am concerned - there is no opposition to the concept of equal pay for work of equal value. We on this side of the chamber are not reactionaries. I am arguing that I do not believe that the Commonwealth Parliament should bc turned into an economic commission to decide this matter. That would be highly dangerous. I do not believe that the Parliament is capable of assessing all the problems involved in this proposition. Indeed, governments of various hues in the past have decided that the method to solve these problems is to create an industrial and arbitral structure which should be charged with the responsibility of determining wage matters.

talk.start.para: - We pay big salaries to the people who examine these matters.
- That is so. We pay judges to decide these matters.
- That is the key to the matter.

- That is the key to the whole problem. The dilemma of honourable senators opposite at present is that they rely upon the industrial strength of the unions as part of the organisational capacity of the Australian Labor Party. From the unions they draw a great deal of their party funds and their organisational support for election campaigns. They are aware of this situation. They are also aware that the areas from which they draw their financial, industrial and organisational strength for election campaigns do not contain the people who will support the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. Honourable senators opposite, knowing that their own supporters do not or will not accept this principle, now seek to use the device of legislative practice inside the Parliament to achieve what they cannot get from their own supporters. I think this was clearly demonstrated by Mr Hawke, advocate for the Australian Council of Trade Unions before the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the national wage case which has only recently concluded. Mr Hawke based his arguments in that case on the maintenance of the basic wage, and the basic wage is based upon the concept of needs according to an old formula that has been used in arbitration tribunals. The basic wage has not been based in the past on the concept of equal pay for work of equal value. In this urgent situation the distinguished and learned advocate of the trade unions, briefed by them to appear before the Arbitration Commission, did not at any stage so far as I have been able to discover raise the thesis of the International Labour Office that there should be equal pay for work of equal value.

speech.para: Why is it not possible for any union to apply to the Arbitration Commission to have this principle embedded in the wage structure of the country? The Arbitration Commission in its judgment which changed the basic wage concept to a total wage concept, as mentioned by Senator Wright, acknowledged that there is a growing understanding and climate of acceptance in Australia for equal pay for work of equal value. The Commission acknowledged the principle in part in the national wage case by giving the same increase of $1 a head in the total wage decision to both male and female workers.

I look forward to the day when equality will be achieved, because I believe that one of the results to flow from it will be increased efficiency in Australian industry. That result will come because, I hope, a great number of women will enter the work force who are infinitely more competent to do some of the available work than are some of the males who are performing that work at present. I had an interesting experience recently in Sydney as Chairman of a Senate select committee. I was standing with my colleagues, one of whom was Senator Branson, on a Scandia ship. We were watching a man with a black box hanging from his shoulder organising the cranes of the ship to unload pre-slung cargo from the bottom of a hold. The thought crossed my mind that that position presented an ideal opportunity for the employment of a woman at high rates of pay. I am quite sure that the job would have been done much more efficiently by a woman than it was done by the man I observed. That is the key to the problem. Not one honourable senator opposite who has a trade union background will go to bis union and advocate, not equal pay for work of equal value, but that there should be opportunities inside the union for women.

talk.start.para: - Of course there are opportunities.

- No, there are not. The truth is that in great areas of the trade union movement in Australia the union members are fighting tooth and nail to do all they possibly can to prevent the entry of women to the work force.
- What about the situation at Broken Hill?

- The situation at Broken Hill is as good an illustration as any. I say that we would be totally recreant if we were to throw overboard the juridical system we have evolved by trial and error over the last 50 or 60 years and were to embark into an economic area by making ad hoc decisions in this Parliament as to what should be done. That juridical system is working very well. The only matter at issue between the Opposition and the Government is the method by which equal pay for work of equal value is to bc effected. The responsibility bears upon honourable senators opposite and members of the Opposition in another place to see that the organisations from which they spring accept their share of the responsibility to achieve in Australia the highly desirable objective of equal pay for work of equal value.

- Senator Tangney has drawn to the attention of the Senate and therefore to the attention of the Australian people the Government's failure to honour its international obligation to take all possible legislative and administrative steps towards achieving equal pay for mcn and women for work of equal value. Despite all the reasons that have been enunciated this afternoon by Government spokesmen, the simple fact of the matter is that the Government has done nothing to honour its international obligation to effect equal pay for work of equal value. It has taken no legislative or administrative steps towards achieving that end. Therefore it is to be condemned by the Australian people.

speech.para: Women members of the Commonwealth Public Service, who are employed by the Government through its own instrumentality - the Commonwealth Public Service Board - are being discriminated against because of the failure to implement the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. They are regarded as second rate citizens by comparison with their male counterparts in the Commonwealth Public Service. This afternoon Government supporters have done a lot of tongue-in-cheek talking on this matter. The Government has had 16 years in which to act positively to honour its international undertaking or obligation, but it constantly refuses to do anything in that direction. It continues to adopt the attitude, as illustrated by its spokesmen this afternoon, that wage determinations are matters for the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It takes that attitude not because it lacks legislative power but simply because of its policy. The Government's case today, as it has been since 1951 when the International Labour Organisation Convention No. 100 and Recommendation No. 90 were signed, is that it is up to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and up to the trade union movement to make appli cation to the arbitration authorities for recognition of this principle. It has been said over and over again by Government spokesmen that they would not oppose such an application if it were made. I think this was repeated today by Senator Gorton but, as Senator Cohen quite rightly asked: Would the Government be prepared to support such an application? Why, as recently as early this year, when addressing a luncheon of the Chamber of Manufactures in Melbourne on the subject of (he failure of the Australian Government to support a request for an increase in the basic wage the Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt) said that the Government wanted to see comparative wage stability this year. But let me come back to the international recommendations.
What was the International Labour Organisation recommendation to which this Government was a party? It was ILO Recommendation No. 90 of 1951 which said:

quote.para: Appropriate action should be taken after consulting with the workers' organisations concerned, or, where such organisations did not exist, with the workers concerned

item.label: (a)
item.para: To ensure the application of the principles of equal remuneration for men and women workers for work of equal value to all employees of central government departments or agencies; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: to encourage the application of the principle to employees of Slate, provincial or local government departments or agencies where these have jurisdiction over rates of remuneration.

speech.para: That principle, which was agreed to by the Menzies. Government in 1951, was clear and simple. It did not say anything about asking the trade union movements of the various countries to request industrial tribunals to agree to the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. It merely said that appropriate action should be taken, after consulting with the workers' organisations concerned.

Now we find that, after having ratified the agreement, every time the Government places an advertisement in the 'Sydney Morning Herald', or any other large metropolitan daily, calling for the filling of vacancies, two rates of pay are advertised, one for females and another for males. In the last Commonwealth of Australia Gazette* of 5th October 1967 at page 5646, the situation with relation to salaries and general conditions is set out in this way:

quote.para: The annual rates of salary are increased as follows, unless otherwise indicated in Public Service Board Circular No. 1967/24:
Adult Males . . Increase of $157 per annum
Adult Females . . Increase of $131 per annum

speech.para: There we see a difference of some$26 per annum in the rates of increase granted to males as compared with females. The same Gazette' also contains this statement:

quote.para: Except for positions exclusively for females, i.e. positions with female designations and those positions which include '(Female)' in the title, the nominal salary range is reduced by $402 when occupied by a female aged 21 years or over or by a junior female where no junior rates are prescribed for the position.

speech.para: So the Commonwealth Government does discriminate to the extent of about $8 a week between the rates paid to male workers and those paid to female workers for performing work which is of the same value. I suggest that in this modern day and age, in this year 1967, bearing in mind that the Government was a party to an International Convention in 1951, it is a scandal that this situation is tolerated.

Incidentally, speaking of the employment of women in the Commonwealth Public Service, it is very interesting to note a reply that was given to a question asked by me on 27th September 1966. The question was:

item.para: How many officers of the Commonwealth Public Service are employed in the First and Second Divisions of the Service?
How many of such officers are females?

speech.para: The then Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Henty, informed me that the Public Service Board had stated that as at 30th June 1966 officers in the First Division of the Commonwealth Public Service numbered twenty-six and that the number in the Second Division was 589. He added that of this latter number a mere two were female officers. While this discrimination exists in 1967, while we have this difference of $8 a week between the rates of pay for male and female workers is it any wonder, that women in the Public Service cannot climb to the higher eschelons?

But I suppose there is something from which direct employees of this Government can take hope. They have been struggling for proper recognition of their just rights for some 17 long years since the International Labour Organisation's recommendation was agreed to by this Government. But it took women in the United States of America 18 years to achieve success. The first Federal Equal Pay Bill for women was introduced in the Congress in 1945. After 18 years of effort by members of Congress, successive Administrations, labour unions, women's groups and others who were interested in the reform, the Federal Equal Pay Act of 1963 finally was enacted. In the 'AFL-CIO News', the American Federation of Labour Journal, of 25th May 1963, under the heading: 'Equal Pay Bill Passes Congress' this statement appeared:

quote.para: The Labor backed Equal Pay for Women Bill moved through both the House and the Senate in less than a week - after an 18-year campaign for a Federal law to outlaw wage discrimination because of sex.
Both the House and the Senate Bills prohibit employers from equalising wages by lowering higher rates for men instead of raising lower wages paid to women.

speech.para: I especially draw the Senate's attention to that in view of the interjection by Senator Cormack, when Senator Cohen was speaking, that arbitration authorities, ratherthan increase the female rate to the male rate, would decrease the male rate to the female rate. The American legislation specifically prohibited the lowering of the higher rates for men instead of raising the lower rates paid for women. The report went on:

quote.para: Equal pay under the legislation would be required for work requiring equal skill, effort and responsibility which is performed under similar working conditions. Wage differentials would be allowed only if based on factors other than sex.

speech.para: But what is the position today? Australia certainly is trailing badly behind the field on this question of equal pay. Since 1951, some 33 countries have ratified the ILO Convention.

talk.start.para: - Are they all applying the principle?

- Thirty-three of them have applied the principle according to a report submitted to the trade union movement by the late Mr Jim Kenny, former Senior Vice-President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and Secretary of the Labour Council of New South Wales. In addition to ILO Convention No. 100, to which this country was a party, there was ILO Convention No.111 which banned discrimination not only on account of sex but also on account of race or creed. The Australian Government has done nothing about ILO Recommendation No. 90 or ILO Convention No. 100 although admittedly it was not prepared to be a signatory to the Convention. Britain, the United States of America, Canada and New Zealand have granted to their Public Service employees equal pay for work of equal value, but Australia has consistently refused to do anything about this matter for some 17 years despite the fact that it was a signatory to the ILO recommendation of 1951. ls it any wonder that in 1965 - a mere 2 years ago - Dr Clair Isbister, an eminent female medical practitioner, said at the annual speech day of Fort Street Girls High School that Australia is a backward country as far as women are concerned?

speech.para: On all the facts this Government has scorned the employment demands of its female officers. This is National Equal Pay Week and the trade union movement is concerned to see that the discrimination which has existed for far too long is brought to an end. The Government will be taught a very severe lesson at the forthcoming Senate election for hell hath no fury like a woman scorned.

talk.start.para: - I was very interested in Senator McClelland's concluding remarks. As he was speaking the thought crossed my mind: Do the trade unions pay female labour in their own offices the male rate of pay?
- 1 have known cases where they would not pay overtime.
- I do not know what the position is.
- In Victoria the answer is Yes.

- It may be. This is a very interesting question and I hope that the Opposition speakers who are to follow mc in this debate will testify, or attempt to testify, on it. The closing days of a sessional period are not an opportune occasion for the introduction of an urgency motion such as the one now before the Senate. I do not think it can be substantiated. It relates to the Government's failure to take all possible legislative and administrative steps towards achieving equal pay for men and women for work of equal value.

speech.para: The first question to which one should apply his attention is: What are these alleged international obligations? Recommendation No. 90 which was before the 34th session of the International Labour Organisation in 1951 related to equal remuneration for mcn and women workers for work of equal value. This was adopted. The Convention requires member states of ILO - Australia was one of them - to promote and, so far as this is consistent with their existing methods of determining rates of remuneration, to ensure the application to all workers of the principle of equal remuneration for men and women workers for work of equal value. The important words in that Convention are: 'So far as this is consistent with their existing methods of determining rates of remuneration'. On that aspect let me refer to some remarks which were made by the present Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt) in 1953 when he was Minister for Labour and National Service. He said:

quote.para: The Commonwealth Government docs not oppose the principle of equal remuneration for men and women for work of equal value.
In the view of the Commonwealth, however, it would be undesirable and unsound to propose legislation to the Commonwealth Parliament for the adoption of this principle--

speech.para: Now come the important words - in advance of a determination to like effect by the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration, which is the supreme arbitral tribunal in Australia. This attitude conforms with that adopted by successive Commonwealth Governments irrespective of Party.

That was the principle in 1953 and it is the principle today. Admittedly there is now no such court as the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration but we have a body which works under another name. The principle is that neither the Parliament nor the Executive should beat the gun in this matter when there is a proper arbitral body to determine it.

On 5th June this year the decision in the national wage case was promulgated. The Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission made some very sound statements on this question of equal pay for males and females. It said:

quote.para: The community is faced with economic, industrial and social challenges arising from the history of female wage fixation. Our adoption of the concept of a total wage has allowed us to take an important step forward in regard to female wages. We have on this occasion deliberately awarded the same increase to adult females and adult males. The recent Clothing Trades decision affirmed the concept of equal margins for adult males and females doing equal work. The extension of that concept to the total wage would involve economic and industrial sequels and call for thorough investigation and debate in which a policy of gradual implementation could be considered.

speech.para: I emphasise that the Commission referred to the involvement of economic and industrial sequels which call for thorough investigation and debate in which a policy of gradual implementation could be considered. The Commission went on:

quote.para: We invite the unions, the employers and the Commonwealth to give careful study to these questions with the knowledge that the Commission is available to assist by conciliation or arbitration in the resolution of the problems.

speech.para: I believe that we should heed those wise words of the specially appointed Commission rather than the words of Senator Tangney's morion which call for a stepping up of legislative and administrative action. Surely we should follow the course laid down in the Commission's judgment.

I think that not since 1949 have the unions advocated in the court this question of equal pay. Now an invitation has been extended to them, to the employers and to the Commonwealth to give careful study to these questions with the knowledge that the Commission is available to assist by conciliation or arbitration in the resolution of the problems. As Mr Holt said in 1953, the Commonwealth is not opposed to the principle of equal pay but it is opposed to beating the gun by beating recognised tribunals to a decision. Surely to goodness, it is appropriate to follow the wise advice given by the Commission in its decision in the national wage case on 5th lune last. 1 was very interested to read the following comment which appears on page 23 of the annual report of the Public Service Board for 1966-67:

quote.para: On 28th June 1967 the High Council of Commonwealth Public Service Organisations requested a meeting with the Board in order to discuss this aspect of the Commission's decision.

speech.para: Seeing the wisdom of the words of the Commission, the High Council made that request. I believe that that is the way in which this matter of equal pay for men and women should be resolved. The invitation extended by the Commission in its judgment on 5th June 1967 should be accepted. Following the lines of the request made by the High Council and using the auspices and good offices of the Commission, the parties should sit down and study this matter. After all, tremendous economic, industrial and social challenges arise from it. Therefore, I do not think it should be treated in the way that Senator Tangney and other members of the Opposition suggest; namely, by legislation of this Parliament or administrative action by any Minister of this Government.

This matter should be discussed with the Commission. It should be argued. The good offices of the Commission should be used with a view to determining it. As I read the Commission's words, it calls for a gradual implementation, not a sudden implementation by legislative or administrative action, as is suggested in the remarks of honourable senators opposite. I consider that it is a matter for gradual movement after investigation and debate. The unions, the employers and the Commonwealth should be the three parties in the discussion. I do not think I can usefully add anything. I believe that the motion should not be carried. The debate has been useful, but on the other hand it has taken up considerable time, which, as Senator Cormack pointed out, could have been used to greater advantage in consideration of the Estimates.

talk.start.para: - The Opposition believes that this matter is so significant and important that it is no less important than any other matter. Therefore our time could not be better used than by debating the need for this great social and economic reform. Although it may be becoming a hardy annual and although the accusation may be made that this matter of urgency has some political propaganda content, a political propaganda campaign can succeed only if it has wide support. If the matter does not have general interest, the motion must fail. This matter will be decided on the interest that there is in it.

speech.para: The indications are that all sections of society believe that there should be some recognition of the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. On other occasions members of the Government parties have cast doubt on the possibility and desirability of the implementation of the principle. They have raised such arguments as the necessity for men and women to accept equal responsibilities. However to-day, in the main, they have said that they believe in the principle, but they have found some reason why the Government should not act as the matter of urgency says it should act. Let us see what validity there is in the claim of members of the Government parties. Let us see what is wrong with this matter of urgency.

Because of the Government's failure to do anything in this field, this matter has been brought forward today. It is significant that it has been brought forward as part of Equal Pay Week which is organised throughout Australia. Firstly it refers to the Government's failure to honour its international obligations. We are told that the Government is not failing to honour such obligations. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gorton) referred to the 1951 International Labour Organisation conference decision that the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be adopted by the member countries and said that Australia had already announced that it would not oppose an application for equal pay. But will the Government go before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or any other tribunal and say that in accordance with the ILO decision it supports the principle of equal pay? The Government is required to do that under the ILO decision, but we have no indication that it is prepared to do it. All that we are told is that it will not oppose an application at this stage.

As Senator Laught pointed out, the terms of the ILO decision were that the principle should be implemented in accordance with the policy of wage fixation in the country concerned. I do not know where members of the Government parties obtained their knowledge of wage fixation methods in Australia, but they have no idea of the method of operation of the tribunal that their Government's legislation brought into being. The Conciliation and Arbitration Act does not set up an arbitration body to decide all wage questions. The emphasis in the Act and the intention when it was introduced was that there be conciliation. The instructions given to the various commissioners and the powers contained in the Act in relation to conferences are designed to get the parties to agree if possible. The wage fixing tribunal has to decide questions only if the parties cannot agree. So the first essential under the Act that honourable senators opposite say we should accept is conciliation and agreement between the parties. In this debate we are asking that the Commonwealth Government, as the biggest employer of female labour in Australia, accept conciliation in accordance with the terms of its Act, try to reach agreement on this principle on which we all agree today, and implement it by a joint application or a consent application to the relevant arbitration tribunal for the fixation of equal wages.

Let us look at what has happened to the wage structure in Australia. The previous argument about equal responsibility no longer has any validity. Previously we had a two-component wage. One component was the basic wage which was based on the needs of the family unit. It could be said that the female was not the basis of the family unit; that the husband had the responsibility of providing for his family and therefore should receive the basic wage. It is claimed that wages are now in excess of the needs of the family unit and are based upon the ability of the economy to pay. Whatever is the ability of the economy to pay, it must have the same ability to pay a female as it has to pay a male. Therefore the argument based on needs - that the needs of a female and a male are not the same - has been completely destroyed. The basis on which living wages are fixed in Australia today - the ability of the economy to pay - must apply to both sexes. The last basic wage decision went a step closer towards equality of wage rates because it provided a flat increase of $1 and declared a total wage. In future the total wage will be based on the ability of the economy to pay the work force, not the different sexes in the work force. This is a start towards equalisation of wages for the sexes. As Senator Wright pointed out, the unions are invited to apply for gradual increases in the total wage. The unions are invited to discuss wage increases with employers on the basis of the capacity of industry to pay.

The South Australian Government, rather than await a decision of the arbitration tribunal, reached agreement with teachers to introduce equal pay for the sexes over a period of 5 years. There is no reason why the Commonwealth should not adopt this policy with its employees. By acting in this way the Commonwealth would be following the principle laid down in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act of discussing matters with employees. In granting equal pay for work of equal value the Commonwealth would be setting an example . to other employers. We favour the implementation of the principle of equal pay over a period of years. The Commonwealth should acknowledge its position as the biggest employer of female labour in Australia. lt should give a lead to other employers. lt should seek to give effect to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act as was intended when the legislation was framed. It should promote the idea of reaching agreement with employees and resorting to arbitration only when all else has failed, lt should give some indication that it will adopt the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. lt is not true that the unions have not been concerned about this matter. We heard Senator Laught in snide fashion ask whether trade unions pay male rates to female employees. I believe that they do. There would be few unions in South Australia which do not pay male rates to female employees. 1 point out that trade unions are not employers within the definition in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Trade unions arc not bound by arbitration awards. Under the South Australian industrial code trade unions are not employers. So they are not bound by awards. But in South Australia the unions have reached agreement with the Federated Clerks Union to pay to their clerical employees the margin awarded to oil company clerks. This is the highest margin for clerks in South Australia. So not only do women employed by trade unions in South Australia get male rates of pay; they also get the highest, award rates for their classification.

In the forefront of organisations in South Australia paying equal rates for work of equal value is the South Australian Public Service. It is paying equal rates by consent. This is what we urge the Commonwealth to do. Arrangements have been made for teachers in South Australia to have equal pay in 5 years. In South Australia barmaids receive equal pay. This is the result of legislative action. There is at the present time before the South Australian Parliament a proposal to alter the industrial code so as to require the industrial tribunal in that State to consider the gradual introduction of equal pay into all industries in South Australia. Senator Cormack doubted whether trade unions would be willing to accept females in industry if the principle of equal pay were adopted. In some cases some unions may be hesitant to see females employed in their industries because female labour is at present a threat to the wage standards of male employees. Trade unions have a responsibility to protect wage standards at all times.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT - Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

talk.start.para: - The motion before the Senate is that the Senate at its rising should adjourn until 9 o'clock tomorrow morning. The motion has been moved by Senator Tangney in order to debate a matter of urgency. It is one which no senator on this side of the chamber could support. The motion has been moved for political purposes. Senator Murphy agreed yesterday that our daily hours of sitting should be extended in order to cope with the work that is before the Senate, although he expressed the wish that we should not sit on Fridays because of the need to attend to matters outside this Parliament. But notwithstanding the busy programme that we have, including the further debate on the Estimates, the Opposition has contrived to initiate a debate on the subject of equal pay for work of equal value. Senator Cavanagh said that no subject was more important than the one now before us. To the best of my knowledge in the last 12 months no honourable senator opposite has raised this matter.
- We realise that there is no hope of the Government considering the matter.

- A number of things have been said in the course of the debate which in my opinion indicate that it is anything but hopeless to expect the Government to deal with this matter sympathetically. I appreciate Senator Tangney's sincerity in raising this matter. On several occasions over the years I have heard her discuss this subject at length. I would say to Senator Tangney that I would be one who would support the general principle as being one which in due course will be applied throughout Australia. I believe that the honourable senator was being entirely unfair and entirely untruthful in asserting that the Government has failed to honour its international obligations.
- I rise to order. I object to the term 'untruthful' applied to me in the context in which it has been used by the honourable senator and I ask that the remark be withdrawn.
- The statement made by the honourable senator could perhaps best be termed as being entirely incorrect.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT- Ord r!
Senator Tangneyhas asked that the word untruthful' be withdrawn.

talk.start.para: - I withdraw the word 'untruthful'. I believe that the honourable senator's comment was designed to mislead people. Not one honourable senator on the Opposition side of the chamber has been willing to justify her words. She said that the Government has failed to honour its international obligations, but it has no international obligation in this matter. In that regard I do not believe that the words she used are fair. I give the honourable senator credit for bringing forward the point that equal work should be rewarded by equal pay. She has stated reasons for raising the argument at this time. It is because equal pay week is upon us. As we have in this community either a day or a week for nearly everything - a hospital week, apprenticeship week and equal pay week - I sincerely hope that our hours of sitting will not be taken up with a debate on the subject of whatever week it happens to be. I know that that would not be the wish of the honourable senator.
- He is giving me an idea.

- The honourable senator has had the idea of dealing with this subject at this time when I believe we should be dealing with the Estimates. The suggestion of equal pay for equal work indicates that in the past there has been discrimination in relation to the volume of work performed by men and women. I have no doubt that eventually equal work will be rewarded on an equal basis whether the person performing the work is male or female.

speech.para: There has been some difference in the treatment of men and women and I imagine that in this growing community there has been a social need for this. If we look back for about 30 years we see that the concepts of need and social responsibility have carried with them the idea that the male basic wage should be related to the normal needs of an average employee with a wife and children. This principle has been to the fore in the Arbitration Court's approach to the basic wage. Through a succession of major cases before the Arbitration Court and, later, the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the concept of the capacity of industry to pay a basic wage has become the dominant principle in assessing a basic wage. Although capacity to pay has become the dominant concept, this does not necessarily mean that there is now no element of the needs concept in the basic wage. As capacity to pay has become the dominant consideration and would apply in the event of an application by unions for a basic wage for females equal to that for males, it would be necessary to consider the effect of a higher female basic wage on the capacity of the economy to meet the added cost. I believe that there would be considerable disturbance to our economy if this concept were adopted too readily.

If we consider the effect upon certain industries today of a female basic wage equal to the male basic wage honourable senators on both sides of the chamber must agree that industries such as the textile industry as they operate in Australia would be put out of business immediately if this concept were brought in at this time. A consideration of our taxation structure would be needed should this concept be adopted. Great consideration would have to be given to the social service benefits which are now payable and, should this principle apply, we would have to consider the effect on the employment of women generally. Surely that is a matter which should be discussed at length by those who propose that we should adopt this principle immediately. In our present situation, rather than increase the female basic wage to the existing level of the male basic wage, it may become necessary in some instances to reduce the male wage so that it is within the capacity of our economy to pay. I believe that equal basic wages at this time would bring about a reduction in the employment of females. 1 believe that this is one consideration to which the trade unions have given serious thought in not pursuing this matter before the industrial courts.

Several honourable senators opposite have dealt with a matter which is basic to this proposal. I refer to convention No. 100 and recommendation 90 of the International Labour Organisation conference. If honourable senators opposite looked honestly at the convention they would agree that Australia has not in any way failed to meet its obligations. The wording read out by Senator Laught said that this equal pay proposition should be brought about in a manner which is consistent with existing methods of determining rates of remuneration. That is what the Commonwealth is now doing and that is what the States also are doing.

talk.start.para: - Some States.

- The honourable senator said that, only some States are doing this. It has already been stated that New South Wales has legislated for equal pay, but I have heard no member of the Opposition telling the Senate what has taken place in New South Wales. The passing of legislation in New South Wales does not mean that women doing equal work are getting the same rates of pay as men. The legislation applies to not more than 10% of female employees in that State. Further, that legislation does not comply with the instruments of the International Labour Organisation on equal pay. For example, it does not apply to women engaged on work which is usually performed by females.
- That is right. That is the whole point.

- Yes. One of the few exceptions in New South Wales are psychiatric nurses where male and female nurses are paid at the same rate. Is it suggested by any honourable senator opposite that the ILO intended that nurses generally would not be paid at the same rate? It must be agreed that that is proof that the concept recommended by the ILO has not been adopted in New South Wales. Honour-' able senators opposite should consider that point. Although they have suggested that the State Governments of New South Wales and South Australia have been taking action along these lines, they must agree that the situation in those States at the moment is not what is now proposed.
- 'But they have started. They have begun.

- I suggest to Senator Tangney that we should consider the attitude of the Federal Government as far back as 1953. Honourable senators will recall that Labor was in Opposition even as far back as 1953. The Commonwealth stated at that time that it did not oppose the principle of equal remuneration for men and women for work of equal value.
- We want something concrete.
- You want something and at times you get it by doing a deal outside the Arbitration Commission, which is something with which we on this side of the House do .not agree.
- The days of your philandering are over.

- Mine are just starting. The Commonwealth has adopted the principle that it will not ratify an agreement unless it can implement it. I suggest that even if the Australian Labor Party were in office today, it would not wish to ratify an agreement unless it could implement it.
- That is the Government's principle.

- The Government will not ratify an agreement unless it can implement it. We could have a situation similar to that which exists in a number of the countries to which Senator Tangney referred. They have ratified an agreement but they will never implement it. It is hypocrisy to do that. The Federal Government, of which I am very pleased to be a supporter, will not become a party to that type of situation. The Federal Government believes that the application of the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be determined by the courts and the other established industrial tribunals. I do not know how we could argue otherwise.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT- Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

talk.start.para: - 1 rise to support the proposal that has been submitted by Senator Tangney. I like others want to congratulate Senator Tangney on the wonderful work she has done in this chamber in relation to women in general and in particular to the subject we are now discussing. 1 am absolutely confident that she will be sitting in this House when a Labor government not only ratifies but implements the International Labour Organisation decisions regarding equal pay for work of equal value. A number of honourable senators from the Government side have said that they believe in the principle of equal pay. 1 suggest that this is the danger which confronts Australian women. People who believe in equal pay for equal work are not prepared to act to implement it.

speech.para: Senator Webster'sstatements were similar to the forebodings of people of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. If one were to read reports of the House of Commons debates in the 1840s, when children were still working in British mines, and were to read the forebodings of the Conservatives of that day, one would note that Senator Webster has uttered similar forebodings in this House this afternoon. Honourable senators opposite have said, in effect, that the time is not opportune to implement this principle of equal pay for equal work. How often have we heard it said that the time is not opportune? In 1842, when girls and boys of 8 and 10 years of age were harnessed to little carts in mines to pull the product out of the mine instead of its being done by horse or other methods, the Conservatives in the House of Commons said that the time was not opportune to alter the situation even though they regretted that they had to use children to do this work.

Today the leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gorton) and other honourable senators opposite have said that the economic implications are too far reaching for the Government to make a decision on this question now. Let me go through the history of this matter. For the whole of my lifetime I have been associated with the trade union movement. Every reform that has been made in the interests of the working class of this nation has been achieved despite the forebodings of the Conservatives. When the working week was reduced from 56 hours to 40 hours we heard the same cliches uttered as were uttered today. The same has been said in relation to equal pay for equal work - a principle that has been contained in ILO conventions for 16 or 17 years. Certainly it has been contained in one of the conventions to which this Government should have subscribed for the whole of its time in office.

I am proud to be able - indeed I welcome the opportunity - to support Senator Tangney on this occasion. Senator Webster said that if the principle of equal pay for equal work was implemented the textile industry would go out of business. In 1842 the Conservatives said that the Bank of England would close if children were not permitted to work in mines. Women and children, in their fight for equality, have been confronted with the fact that although people believe in a principle they are never willing to implement it. There was a fight when women wanted the right to vote. There was a fight when they wanted to achieve equality in other fields - even for the right to stand for election to Parliament. It was not until the 1 920s that women in Victoria were permitted to stand for election to Parliament. The same argument that is being used today can be found in the Hansard reports of that period.

On this occasion Government supporters have done their utmost to try to defend a position which is absolutely indefensible. They have tried to show that they are as keen as we are to implement the policy of equal pay for equal work. The reason why they have to get up and say that they believe in this principle is that it is contained in the official federal platform of the Liberal Party of Australia, as approved by the Federal Council of that Party. Clauses 74 to 92 deal with employment and industry. Clause 85 states that one of the objectives of the Party is the recognition of the principle of equal remuneration for men and women for work of equal value.

talk.start.para: - I was going to read it. The honourable senator has saved my doing it.

- Senator Sim was prepared to read it out, but he is not prepared to implement it. That is the difference between members of the Labor Party and Government supporters. Government supporters are not prepared to buck the official policy of the Party. They say: 'Although this Is a matter with which we agree in principle, in no circumstances must we implement it.' It has been argued that arbitration tribunals, not the Government, should implement this principle. Let me throw this argument into the melting pot and see what the result will be. The Government would not break any precedent if it legislated or moved into the administrative field to implement the principle of equal pay for equal work. There is a precedent for this move. In at least four States of the Commonwealth legislation has been introduced to provide for equal pay for equal work.

speech.para: The precedent has also been established by arbitration tribunals. I have worked in industries in which the awards provide for equal pay. In the case of tram drivers in Victoria, provision for the payment of equal pay was inserted in the award with the cooperation of the State Government. Many other awards in Victoria provide for equal pay for equal work. The principle applies in some of the Commonwealth services and it also applies in some State services. Senator Cohen referred to arbitration authorities which have indicated quite clearly that they believe that the economic and social problems associated with equal pay for equal work are such that they should be handled at a legislative level.

The arguments that have been advanced one after another by honourable senators opposite are not worthy of any consideration. Although this Government professes to believe in the principle of equal pay for work of equal value, since at least 1953 it has said that that principle cannot be implemented today or tomorrow. The present Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt) is on record as saying in 1958 that he was not opposed to the principle of equal pay for equal work. If that is the Government's policy, it should do something positive to assist in the conciliatory discussions that would take place if applications were made to have this principle implemented. The Government could assist greatly by ensuring that the arbitration tribunals receive sympathetically any application from the trade union movement instead of advocating before the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, as it has done in national wage cases in recent years, that the basic wage, as it was previously, and now the total wage not be increased, because the economy of the country cannot stand an increase.

I believe that the Australian Labor Party this afternoon has done a great service to the women of Australia and indeed to the cause of equal pay throughout Australia. We on this side of the Senate this afternoon have clearly shown that the Government does not intend at any time to implement any of the decisions of the International Labour Organisation relating to equal pay or to assist employees in any application for implementation of this principle. What honourable senators opposite are saying they are saying in terms in which for centuries reforms aimed at adoption of the principle of equal pay and equal rights throughout a nation have been opposed. I believe that I have said sufficient, Mr Deputy President, to indicate that we on this side of the chamber want equal pay for equal work to be implemented as quickly as possible. I now intend to test the sincerity of the Government in relation to the principles upon which it professes to stand. Accordingly, 1 move:

quote.para: That the question be now put.

division.header.para: Question put. The Senate divided. (The President - Senator Sir Alister McMullin)

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: - Mr Deputy President, we have become rather accustomed to urgency motions on matters having no urgency. Since 19tb April, the Australian Labor Party has presented six urgency motions. In addition, there has been one proposed by Senator McManus. That was the only one relating to a matter that had any degree of urgency. It concerned the soliciting of funds for North Vietnam. Since 19th April, we have spent almost 18 hours discussing matters of no urgency. What urgency was there about water conservation that it should have been debated on 19th April? On 22nd August, the Chowilla Dam project was discussed as a matter of urgency. I put it frankly to Senator O'Byrne, who is interjecting, that nothing that is said here will alter the situation in Victoria. Was there any need to debate that project as a matter of urgency on 22nd August? Trade with China was another subject raised as a matter of urgency. But that was of no urgency at all. Such trade has been going on for years. So what was the urgency that required discussion of it here? Power and water development projects in Queensland also were discussed in a debate on an urgency motion. The only urgency seen by the Opposition then was due to the fact that an election was pending in Queensland. Yesterday, we debated an urgency motion relating to losses to fruit growers caused by the closure of the Suez Canal and consequent delays to shipping. This may be a matter of great importance to the fruit growers of South Australia and Tasmania, but what was the urgency that required its discussion in the Senate?

speech.para: I now come to the matter that is before us today - equal pay for equal work. The terms in which the motion of urgency has been proposed are interesting. The adjournment of the Senate has been proposed for the purpose of discussing a matter of urgency, namely:

quote.para: The Government's failure to honour its international obligations and to take all possible legislative and administrative steps towards achieving equal pay for men and women for work of equal value.

speech.para: Senator Wrightshowed that the charge that the Government has failed to honour its international obligations is absolutely without foundation. I shall come back to that later. I recognise that the subject of equal pay for work of equal value is important, but what is the urgency that requires it to be discussed today? I understand that an equal pay week is being held. Apparently, therefore, there has suddenly developed an urgent need to devote 3 hours of the Senate's time to a debate on this subject today, though we have on the business paper other matters of exceedingly great importance, particularly the proposed expenditures of the Commonwealth for the current financial year. We have to discuss these proposed expenditures in considerable detail.

talk.start.para: - What about Fathers Day?

- This may be the next one. Even if this motion were carried, what effect would it have? Would it bring equal pay for equal work any nearer? I do not think it would. One is left to draw only one conclusion, that is, that this is no more than another political propaganda exercise, to try to gain, with a Senate election coming on, some kudos by posing as great champions of equal pay for women. The Government has made its attitude over many years quite clear. I am indebted to Senator Poyser for quoting from the Liberal Parly platform. I do not run away from that, lt is because of this platform that we stand and say that we do not oppose the principle of equal pay. We support it and have supported it for years. Our attitude :s quite clear. We believe that this is not a matter for governments to legislate on. This is a matter for 'he appropriate wages tribunals of Australia to decide upon.
- Why is it in the Liberal Party policy if it is nol a matter for legislation?
- That is an intelligent interjection. It is in our policy because we accept the principle of equal pay for equal work but this does not bind the Government.
- Why does not the Government legislate for it?

- I am very charitable with the honourable senator but it may not last much longer. This does not bind the Government to legislate. The Government's attitude is quite clear. It is accepted and acknowledged by the Party that this is a matter for the wages tribunals of Australia to decide upon. This is a matter of great economic importance to Australia. Senator Wheeldon might find it a laughing matter. Indeed, he apparently regards the whole question of equal pay for equal work as a laughing matter. This may be the Opposition's attitude. This matter may be brought up today as some sort of joke, because ever since I started to speak Senator Wheeldon has been laughing about it. He apparently finds it a laughing matter. To us, it is not. Where we disagree with the Opposition is on the question of who makes this decision, whether it is the Government by legislation or the properly constituted wages tribunals. We stand quite clearly and unequivocally on this issue. It is a matter to be decided by the wages tribunals and it should have been brought before them. When I looked at the records I found that the Australian Council of Trade Unions raised this matter before the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Court in 1949 and it has not raised the matter since. It could have done so at the last wages hearing but it did not do so. 1 do not think that any trade unions have raised this matter with their properly constituted wages tribunals. They do not want to. If this is a matter of some great principle, of great urgency, of great moment, why did not the ACTU raise it again?

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Drake-Brockman) - Order! The time allowed for debate on this motion having expired, the Senate will proceed to the next business.
