debate.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT- The President has received a letter from Senator Branson as follows:

quote.para: My dear President,

debate.para: I hereby request my immediate discharge on the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, my reasons being:

item.para: That the Committee cannot fulfil) a useful purpose so long as it can only deal with matters that are referred to it by the Minister and not by the Parliament.

The particular circumstances at the moment whereby the Minister referred to the Committee only the question of freehold land in the ACT, despite the fact that a unanimous request was made by the Committee to refer the related questions of city, commercial, and industrial leases in the ACT.

quote.para: Yours sincerely,

item.label: G.
item.para: H. BRANSON

talk.start.para: - by leave - I move:

quote.para: That Senator Branson be discharged from attendance as a member of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory.

speech.para: I shall at a later stage, after we have had more time to consider the matter, be proposing a motion for a senator to replace him on that Committee.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - 1. oppose the motion. It is about time that we had men with independent minds prepared to sit on Committees in which they may be outvoted. The Senate will do a great disservice to the people of Canberra if it accepts Senator Branson's resignation. He should be asked to reconsider the whole matter and we should not pass this motion. It is not often that we see a member of a party prepared to get up and buck his party. I know he has done this on previous occasions. It means, of course, the end of preferment for him but I do not think that that worries Senator Branson. When someone of an independent spirit is prepared to rise and state a case but finds that he has to resign in order to do so it is a sad day for the Parliament if it accepts his resignation.

speech.para: This affects all of the people of Canberra, not just the Minister himself. Senator Branson's reasons are valid reasons for the Government to take note of. The Government should try to change the position. Senator Branson should stay on the Committee until such time as, by maintaining this attitude, he forces the Government to change the terms of reference of the Committee. I for one am prepared to- oppose the motion and ask Senator Branson to reconsider bis resignation with a view to the Parliament's obtaining a change in the terms of reference.

talk.start.para: - I want to speak briefly in opposition to the motion. If a man wants to resign I do not think we can do other than accept his resignation. But this resignation emphasises the futility of this Committee which can do nothing or has very limited power and seems to be a waste of time. The resignation is being made as a protest at the limited power being given to the Committee at a time when the senator resigning from it believes there is work for the Committee to do. On the question of whether or not the complaint is justified I find some support from the remarks last night of Senator Toohey, who is a delegate from the Australian Labor Party to this Committee. He said that there was justification for the grievance of Senator Branson and that it may be only a short time before all members of the Committee find it necessary to follow this example.

speech.para: When members of the Committee seem almost unanimous in believing that the Committee cannot function as it should function, rather than just replace one member of it who has emphasised and shown up this weakness we should seek some declaration from the Government or the Minister on how this weakness is to be overcome, or we should seek from the Senate an expression that it does not approve of the continuation of a Committee, which practically all members of it find cannot function in an efficient and proper manner in carrying out the work that the Parliament which appointed it thought it should carry out.

talk.start.para: - I realise that Senator Branson has freedom of choice in the action he is taking. 1 am sure that he has given the matter consideration. However, I would like to tell honourable senators that during the period of time 1 served on the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory I found it to bc the most frustrating, useless and timewasting exercise that I have yet been associated with in the Parliament. In this particular sphere the Parliament is only a tool of the Executive. References to the Committee are sent along in the manner of dropping a few crumbs for it to feed on while the main decisions are being made on the Executive and bureaucratic level.
- The decisions have already been made.

- That is so. The Committee has made great efforts to establish a dialogue and to get communication with the Minister, to try to get through the point that it is interested in the development of Canberra from the great concept that Burley Griffon originally offered for us to follow in the manner of the land itself and the planning of the city. Canberra is regarded as a magnificently planned city. The plan should be continued and developed under the watchful eye of the Parliament itself. Yet this Committee, which is supposed to have the responsibility of carrying out its duties on behalf of fellow members of the Parliament and to report back to the Parliament on what is happening, is given tasks that stultify the hopes of its members that they can contribute something to the planning of the development of Canberra.

speech.para: T quite understand Senator Branson's feelings. When I was a member of the Committee we were bogged down in correspondence with Mr Freeth, the Minister for the Interior at that time. In his correspondence he gave us to understand that we did not count for anything and that we were only wasting our time in corresponding with him. I felt then exactly as Senator Branson feels now. I wanted to throw in the towel. I reconsidered my position and stayed on the Committee until I had served my period of time. I sympathise with the honourable senator and I understand the agony he has been through because of the frustration encountered as a member of a committee which is able to get nowhere very slowly.

talk.start.para: - So that this matter can be resolved before the suspension of the sitting I wish to state that I could not withdraw my request to be discharged from the Committee. If I were to do so I believe that I would lay myself open to the charge that I was engaging in political manoeuvre. I would not want my sincerity doubted. I am grateful for what has been said. If my resignation should bring forth what I think the charter of the Committee should be, that would be a different matter. Perhaps in the future I would put my name forward and again seek to be appointed to the Committee, but at this time I could not withdraw my request for discharge from the Committee.

- I will be brief. I also oppose the motion, for the reasons that have already been put forward. In opposing the motion we have a feeling of sympathy for Senator Branson in being placed in the intolerable position of being a Liberal Party member of a Committee appointed to advise a member of the Australian Country Party. It is most unfortunate that this coalition is having a disastrous impact, not only on members of committees but also on members of the Cabinet who are finding the position intolerable. No doubt the precedent set today will be followed by a number of Ministers - even senior Ministers - and the coalition will be finished. I believe we ought to feel some sympathy for Senator Branson, who as a member of the Liberal Party has found it intolerable to work under a Minister who is a member of the Australian Country Party.

- I am afraid that 1 was outside the chamber when the motion was proposed. 1 understand that Senator Branson has been asked to reconsider his resignation from the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. If you will permit me, Sir, as a member of that Committee, I would like to point out to the Senate, as I did during the debate on the adjournment of the Senate last night, that I can understand readily the frustration experienced by Senator Branson. Quite frankly, I was considering very seriously whether I should follow his example. However, certain difficulties are involved. I was appointed to the Committee as a member of the Opposition and I thought that I should first of all convey to my Party any decision I would make. I think the Senate should understand that it is not of much use for both Houses of the Parliament to appoint committees to do specific things if useful work and activity do not spring from the efforts of those committees.

speech.para: In the time that I have been a member of this Committee - it is a considerable period - it has seemed to me that there is very little reason for the continued existence of the Committee in the present circumstances. Mr Anthony, the former Minister for the Interior, probably under pressure of rumblings inside the Committee, decided to refer to it leases of residential sites in the Australian Capital Territory and an inquiry into this activity is to take place. I believe that some useful work might spring from such an inquiry.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - I rise to a point of order. Have you, Mr. Deputy President, noticed the time?

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Drake-Brockman) - Order! There is no substance in the point of order.

talk.start.para: - May I continue my remarks after the suspension of the sitting? I do not wish to detain the Senate.

speech.para: Sitting suspended from 6.2 to 8.0 p.m.

talk.start.para: - Before the suspension of the sitting I was informing the Senate that the Australian Capital Territory Committee had felt some disquiet for some time because of the serious restrictions placed upon its activities by the charter under which it operates. I do not want to misinform the Senate or lead the Senate to believe that this is something that has just happened of recent date. We knew, of course, when we first went on to the Committee that we would, deal only with such matters as were referred to us by the Minister for the Interior. As one who takes a very keen interest in the development and growth of Canberra, I was hoping over the long period that I have been associated with the Committee that the Minister would see fit to refer many more matters to it. I was hoping that he would refer to us matters covering a much wider scope than those with which we have been dealing. This feeling, communicating itself to other members of the Committee, has culminated in the matter under discussion tonight - Senator Branson's resignation from the Committee. I do not intend to canvass Senator Branson's resignation very much other than to say that, in the light of circumstances now, he might feel that he would like to reconsider his decision. But that is up to him. I for one feel that it would not bc proper for the rest of the Committee to adopt the stand he has taken, particularly in view of the fact that the Minister has now indicated that he is prepared to refer to the Committee the question of the control of the sub-division of freehold lands in the Australian Capital Territory.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - When did he do that?

- I do not want to say anything that is wrong, but I think this may have some connection with a recent action of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I do not want to confuse the issue by introducing a matter which is not yet before the Senate but which may have some relation to the present discussion, lt is quite obvious, that the decision of the Minister could be related to the circumstances surrounding a recent action of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. Be that as it may, at least the proposal to give the Committee, for the first time since I have been associated with it, an opportunity to get its teeth into something that will be of interest to it and perhaps of some benefit to the citizens of Canberra is a good one. This proposal was accepted by the Australian Capital Territory Committee at its meeting, and we also agreed unanimously to ask the Minister to refer to the Committee for similar inquiry questions relating to city industrial and commercial leases for it is in this field that a considerable amount of dissatisfaction and disquiet has been expressed.
- He has been asked to do that in the past and refused.

- That is so but the Committee did not accept that as final. It requested the Minister to reconsider his attitude and refer to the Committee questions relating to industrial and commercial leases in the city, about which there has been so much criticism. It might be as well if I inform the Senate that over the last 3 or 4 months, since this question of industrial and commercial leases became a burning one, the Committee has been inundated with correspondence from business concerns and citizens who feel that they are being unjustly treated under the existing system. Some have claimed that others have secured unfair advantages as a result of decisions made with respect to commercial and industrial leases in the city. I have a pile of this type of correspondence, as has every other member of the Committee and no doubt the people who sent it in acted in the belief that this Committee had some real authority. Unfortunately we have had to inform our correspondents that this is not so. In effect, we had to admit - reluctantly on my part - that the Committee was little more than a rubber stamp. The present set up in relation to commercial and industrial leases in the city has become a matter of great public interest and, as I said earlier, 1 think the Senate, should be told something about it.

speech.para: It might be appropriate also if I told the Senate about some of the Committee's activities. The title 'Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory Committee' is a very imposing one. It certainly lends itself to the thought that the Committee would be considering all sorts of interesting matters relating to the development and progress of the ACT. But the Committee acts only when the Minister thinks fit to refer to it a matter such as the sub-division of a new area, and the strict limitations placed upon the Committee's activities are starkly revealed by the fact that it has power to consider only such aspects as the width of roads, access to blocks and the location of roads surrounding shopping centres. Our activities virtually begin and end at that level.

There is one point that I wish to make to the Senate and I think the Senate should digest it well. In carrying out the restricted activities that I have mentioned, the Committee meets officers of the Department of Interior and other officers connected wilh progress and developmental activities. They are all men of tremendous ability and I emphasise that they often have much greater powers and authority than have the men who comprise this Committee. Indeed, when we measure the meagre amount of Authority which we have as members of the Committee against that of the men who advise the Committee from time to time on the limited activities which I have outlined, we must wonder whether the Committee ought to be given much more authority.

There is no doubt whatever in my mind that the Committee will not be able to function properly until such time as the Minister sees fit to widen its activities considerably and greatly increase its authority. An all parly committee of both houses of the Parliament should be able to lend a tremendous amount of drive and assistance to the development of the ACT. More important still, it could act as a buffer between the big brotherism which seems to have developed at the top level and the people of the ACT who feel they are being very sadly used in many directions in connection with i he subdivision of freehold land and with commercial and industrial leases in the city. Both of these matters are giving rise to a great deal of concern in the ACT at the present time.

I have with me some of the correspondence which 1 have no doubt has been sent to all members of that Committee. One letter from George Wimpey and Co. covers 30 or 40 pages. There are submissions from a Mr Kousal and there is a legal opinion regarding land development by private enterprise. There is a great deal of correspondence of a similar character, all indicating the concern that the people of the ACT, both businessmen and private citizens, feel because their rights are not being protected properly as a result of the Minister refusing to give the Committee an opportunity to deal with these matters and to assist them. lt is my earnest hope that the action Senator Branson has taken - somewhat precipitate, perhaps, but nevertheless taken in good faith, I am sure, and with the best of intentions - will have one of two beneficial results. I hope, firstly, that the Minister will decide that this Committee must act in a wider sense and have greater authority than it has at present, or secondly, that at some stage in the not too distant future the other members of the Committee may feel impelled to take the same kind of action as was taken by Senator Branson.

The DEPUTY PRESIDENT- Order! I have allowed this debate to roam over a wide field but I now ask honourable senators to confine their remarks to the terms of the motion and to the material in Senators Branson's letter. I call Senator Devitt.

talk.start.para: - At the outset let me say that I very much regret the action that Senator Branson has taken on this occasion. Quite frankly, I question whether any real benefit will flow from it having regard to the circumstances as they exist today. I know the great interest that Senator Branson has in this matter and

speech.para: I would much prefer that he remain with the Committee to give his fellow members the benefit of his knowledge and tremendous interest. I believe that his withdrawal from this Committee will not strengthen it; rather it will have the effect of weakening it. I believe also that if other members of the Committee become as frustrated as I know he has become about the emasculated role of the Committee, to use his words, we will have ultimately a committee completely compliant, completely under the domination and control of the Minister and completely devoid of any real purpose or functional ability. So I suggest to him that he reconsider his decision.

The lack of proper planning over past years of the affairs of the Australian Capital Territory has given rise to the feeling of frustration which exists not only in the mind of Senator Branson - it caused him to dissociate himself from the affairs of the Committee - but also in the minds of other members of the Committee. In 1948 or 1949 one of my Tasmanian colleagues, the late Mr J. R. H. Cole, who was then Town Clerk of Hobart, came to the ACT and reported on the setting up of a local government authority for this area. On at least one occasion, and possibly on two occasions, since then committees of the Senate have been set up to examine the general question of ACT affairs.

As a result of the interpretation of city area leases, quite a number of problems have arisen concerning which members of the Committee have been bombarded with correspondence from many sections of the Canberra community asking that some action be taken to put the matter on a proper basis. Of course the whole point is that the Committee has no power unless the Minister is prepared to refer to it matters of consideration.

talk.start.para: - There is a new Minister for the Interior now and that might help.

- Yes, and I feel rather sorry that he is coming into office at a time when the Committee looks like falling apart. Other honourable senators would probably have a better appreciation of his ability and his attitude to the ACT than I have but I hope that he has those qualities in greater measure than did the previous incumbent of the office. I assume that this Committee was set up to assist in the development of the ACT and I hope that the new Minister, in his wisdom and out of the goodness of his heart and with all the other motivations that one would expect from a Minister, will call upon this Committee to determine many of the complex questions which are bedevilling the ACT at the present time.
- It is like the broadcasting and television committee.

- There are many such committees and there must be a great number of pigeonholes filled with reports. As a member of this Committee I feel duty bound to express my opinion on what is happening. I have had a good deal of experience in the field of local government in my State and I know that to obtain proper control of an area one must follow the processes laid down. In the post-war years it has been common practice in the better run municipalities to set up zoning areas and to define residential areas, industrial areas and rural localities. The districts are properly zoned and the people concerned have the right to examine the relevant plans and, if they feel aggrieved, to protest against them. They have recourse lo a proper authority to determine the form that the protest will take and that protest ultimately finds its way to a properly constituted court where they have a right to state their case for or against various proposals.

speech.para: No such right exists in the ACT. We recently had before the Senate an ordinance which deprived people in residential areas of the right to institute legal proceedings. The people of the Territory should be on a paT with people in the remainder of Australia. They should be able to exercise their civil right of taking legal action, if necessary, to protect their leases. At the present time they may not take legal action unless the Minister gives permission for that to be done. Nowhere else in Australia are the people denied their civil rights to the extent that they are in the ACT.

These are the questions which are perplexing the Committee which regards itself as a responsible body charged with protecting the rights of the people of this Territory. I do not want to prolong this debate-

talk.start.para: - Hear, hear!

- I know that the Government does not like this but honourable senators opposite should bear in mind that we did not precipitate this position. Senator Branson, one of their own colleagues, did so. This is quite a serious matter. It concerns the affairs of about 110,000 people in the ACT. This Territory comes under the control of the Government which ultimately, at the top level, is charged with the responsibility of ensuring that the laws of this land are observed. Yet something that is enshrined in our system in the rest of Australia is denied to the people of this Territory. Surely that is not good enough. I sincerely hope that this matter will be taken up with the Minister for the Interior (Mr Nixon) when he has settled into his new position. I assure the Senate that the members of the Joint Committee will be quite accommodating in allowing him to settle into his new duties and responsibilities, but we will want to, be able to guide him and assist him so that the people of the ACT can have the same protection of law and the same rights as the people in any other part of Australia.

- The interest that honourable senators opposite have taken in this matter moves one almost to tears. Whatever caused Senator Branson to take the action that, he has taken, I am sure that he is now very sorry that he took that action.
- He was driven to it.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT- Order! The Senate will come to order.

talk.start.para: - Those of us who have been in the Senate for quite a while understand very well the motives of honourable senators opposite in prolonging this debate. They want to keep away from any mention of. defence and any discussion of the defence estimates.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT- Order! I suggest that the Minister should come back to the subject of the debate.

talk.start.para: - The point that I am making is that honourable senators opposite do not want, in any circumstances, to come to a discussion of the defence estimates or to talk about defence. In another place yesterday-
- Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask that the Minister be required to keep to the subject matter of the debate.

- I wish to speak to the point of order. At this stage Senator Henty is entitled to canvass the arguments of the Opposition and question their integrity. He is entitled to make his speech and the Leader of the Opposition has no right under any standing order to try to put Senator Henty out of countenance.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT - If the
Minister confines his remarks to the motion and the contents of Senator Branson's letter he will be in order.

talk.start.para: - I would hate to be out of order, but I do not think that in discussing the contents of Senator Branson's letter we should allow the opportunity to pass v without mentioning Senator Devitt's reference to a visit to this city in the very distant past when the Labor Party happened to be in office. It was such a long time ago that I compliment the honourable senator on his memory. I think it was in 1947 or 1948 that the Town Clerk of Hobart came to Canberra to advise on the matter of local government. Members of the Opposition are pushed to advancing that type of argument in order to make sure that time passes by and that no reference is made to the matter of defence which, as you are well aware, Mr Deputy President, is listed to be debated as soon as this motion is dealt with. Of course, yesterday the Leader of the Opposition in another place (Mr Whitlam) ran away from-
- Again I raise a point of order. I ask that the Minister be required to keep to the subject matter of the debate.

- Speaking to the point of order, I suggest that if, every time an honourable senator on the Government side, when speaking in a debate, refers to what he believes to be the purpose for which that debate is being continued and to what he believes to be the reason why a matter that is on the notice paper is being deferred by wasting time, the Leader of the Opposition is to stand up and claim that the honourable senator is out of order, debate and public discussion in this chamber will be stifled.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT- A short time ago the Chair warned an honourable senator that the debate was going too far away from the subject matter. I believe that the previous speaker got well away from the subject matter in some instances and that it is only fair that the Minister for Supply should be allowed to answer him. But I ask the Minister to come back to the subject matter of the debate.

talk.start.para: - There are times when I think the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Murphy) has reached the stage where he believes that the Senate is a Sunday school, because he is so sensitive. Whenever anything is said about defence, he is so sensitive that he must stand up and take a point of order. Members of the Opposition have been running away from that matter at every opportunity. Whenever it is raised, up they pop like a jack-in-a-box, raising points of order. We have listened to speaker after speaker from the Opposition side. They were not interrupted by interjections by us. They canvassed a wide range of matters. They wandered away from the point. But when one speaker from this side of the chamber stands up and points out the facts of life - namely that the members of the Opposition are running away from a debate on another subject; that they a.-e only trying to waste time; that they want to make sure that we do not get down to debating the defence of this country and the commitment of Australian troops to Vietnam
- I raise a point of order for the third time. Standing order 419 states:

quote.para: No Senator shall digress from the subject matter of any Question under discussion; nor anticipate the discussion of any subject which appears on the Notice Paper.

speech.para: The Minister is repeatedly and flagrantly disregarding warnings that you have given, Mr Deputy President. The matters that are listed to come up for debate will be debated in their order. The Minister is deliberately defying the instruction that you have given. I ask you to require him to keep to the subject matter under discussion and not to deal deliberately with other matters in the way that he has been doing.

talk.start.para: - Speaking to the point of order, I suggest that it cannot be argued for a moment that Senator Henty is anticipating the discussion of something that is on the notice paper. What he is doing is regretting that the discussion o£ the defence estimates, which are listed on the notice paper, is being postponed by the Opposition. We have heard five Opposition speakers in a row speaking not to the motion before the Chair, which is that an honourable senator he discharged from service on a committee at his own request, but on the operations of a committee that is operating under terms of reference laid down by this Parliament. 1 suggest to you, Mr Deputy President, that in those circumstances there is no substance in a point of order which claims that an honourable senator on this side of the chamber is not entitled to regret that members of the Opposition have been speaking on something which is not the subject matter of the debate and to regret that the discussion of the defence estimates is being put off. I suggest that if he does that he is not anticipating that discussion.

- In speaking to the point of order, Mr Deputy President, I ask you to have the motion before the Chair read so that Senator Henty will know what we are debating. He was not in the chamber when the letter was read.
- The honourable senator should know that 1 have a loudspeaker in my office.
- Then his hearing must be a little faulty, because it does not appear that he knows what the motion is. So I would like you to have the motion before the Chair read.

- Mr Deputy President, I wish to speak to the point of order. talk.start.para: - Senator Wright has not stated the position properly. The obligation of a senator is to serve on a Committee if he is appointed to it. He may be appointed to a committee against his will, but it is his obligation and his duty to serve unless he is excused by the Senate. If he is a member of a committee his obligation is still to serve unless the Senate excuses him by a motion such as this. It is not a right of a senator to be excused from a committee; it is an indulgence which the Senate grants to him. In this case much has been said about the motives which have actuated Senator Branson in asking to be discharged from the Committee. Iri is is not a mere case of some personal problem, some over-work or something of that nature which would induce the Senate, without question or discussion, to accede to his request. The basis upon which he made his request was such as to raise a serious question as to whether it should be granted. I understand that Senator Branson wishes to persist with his request. I understand also that the suggestion which has been made very well by Senator Bishop, that the matter should be stood over in order that further consideration may be given, will not be accepted. In these circumstances, notwithstanding the grave problems which have been raised by Senator Branson in detailing the circumstances which have caused him to ask for his discharge, I believe that the Senate should accede to his request and that we should accept this motion proposed by the Government.

- in reply - If I may say so, I believe that the remarks that have just been made by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Murphy) are the only sensible remarks that I have heard from the Opposition in the course of this debate. The motion which is before the Senate at the moment is not a Government motion. It is not a motion that the Government wanted to move, nor is it one that I wanted to move. It arises out of a letter written by a senator to the President asking for discharge from duties on a committee of the Senate. In accordance with the wishes expressed by that senator in that letter, in the normal course of Senate business I moved, on his behalf, that the Senate should discharge him from the duties from which he had asked to be discharged. I did so because that was the only way in which he could be formally discharged from that duty. It could only be done by a motion of the Senate. How silly it would be if the Senate were to say no in spite of this request, if it were to say that it would not accede to his request and would not agree to discharge him from his duties. In that event he would still be formally a member of the Committee, but nobody could make him go and work on the Committee. Nobody could arraign him and say that he must give his mind to the Committee. Surely it would not be suggested that any honourable senator who did not want to work on a committee and who had asked to be relieved from it could be forced to work on it.

speech.para: This is a situation which has arisen before. I have been informed by the Clerk of the Senate that never on any occasion has a senator who has come to the Senate and said, as a member of a committee, that he sought leave to be discharged from his duties been refused leave of the Senate to be discharged. It is his decision and his request. This is not the result of a decision by me and does not arise from a request by the Government; it is a request by a particular senator and is put to the Senate. These terms of reference are not laid down by a Minister; they are the result of resolutions by both Houses. The result of a vote on the request of a particular senator to be relieved of his duties would in no way affect the position. For these reasons and so that we can get on with some of the country's business - though this is the country's business, too - I suggest to the Senate that the wishes of one of its members as expressed to the President and as conveyed in my motion be acceded to.

speech.para: This Bill declares the rates of income tax for the financial year 1967-68 on income of certain superannuation funds, trust estates and members of partnerships. The rates declared by the Bill are special rates which were declared for the first time in relation to the 1965-66 financial year for the purposes of legislation introduced in 1964 to counter tax avoidance arrangements brought to the Governments attention in the 1961 report of the Commonwealth Committee on Taxation. The rates have remained unchanged since they were originally introduced, and no change is proposed for the current financial year.

For income of a trust estate, other than a deceased estate, to which no beneficiary is presently entitled and which is not taxed as if it were the income of one individual, the rate declared by the Bill is 50%. For income from a share in a partnership over which a person lacks, or is deemed to lack, real and effective control and disposal, the Bill imposes a further rate of tax sufficient to bring the aggregate rate on the income up to 50%. If a taxpayer's average personal rate of tax is 50% or more, no further tax is imposed under this Bill.

A rate of 50% is also declared foi the taxable income of a superannuation fund that is not exempt from tax. This rate does not apply, however, to the investment income of a fund that is subject to tax only through the fund's failure to comply with the 30/20 rule concerning investments in public securities. The rates on this income are those contained in the Income Tax Bill 1967 and are the same as applied last year. 1 commend the Bill to the Senate.

speech.para: The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to give effect to proposals announced by the Treasurer (Mr McMahon) in his Budget Speech. These proposals relate to concessional deductions and to provisions affecting primary producers. The Bill proposes an increase of $26 in the amounts of concessional deductions allowable for the maintenance of dependants. The deductions for a spouse, a daughter-housekeeper, a housekeeper, an invalid relative and a parent will each be increased from $286 to $312. The deductions for a student child under 21 years of age and one child under 16 years of age will be increased from $182 to $208, and for each other child under 16 years of age from $130 to $156.

An increase of $400 is proposed in the amount of the concessional deduction for payments by a taxpayer to provide super annuation or insurance benefits for himself and his family. The new limit will be $1,200 for each income year. These increases in the concessional deductions will apply to assessments for the 1967-68 income year and subsequent years. For salary and wage earners, the benefits from the increased dependants' allowances are being reflected in reduced tax instalment deductions which have operated as from 1st October.

The remaining amendments proposed by the Bill apply to primary producers. One amendment proposed will apply to primary producers who, because of drought, fire or flood, are forced to sell livestock. Under the present law, a primary producer who is forced to sell livestock in these circumstances may elect to have the profits of the sale taxed over a period of 5 years if the proceeds of the sale are used principally for the purpose of restocking. The Bill proposes an alternative method of bringing the profits of a forced sale to account for income tax purposes. Broadly, a primary producer who uses the proceeds of a forced sale principally for restocking may, in respect of sales in 1967-68 or a subsequent year, elect to have the profit on the sale applied to reduce the cost for income tax purposes of the replacement stock. This will have the effect of deferring payment of tax on the proceeds of a forced sale until the replacement stock are sold in the normal course of business. In some cases stock may be replaced by breeding rather than by purchase. In these circumstances, it is proposed that a primary producer may specify an amount of the profit of the forced sale to be included in his assessable income of the year in which natural increase is bred. If, by the end of the fifth year after the year in which the forced sale occurred, any amount of the profits of the sale has not been applied in either of the ways I have mentioned, the amount will be included in the assessable income of that year. In the past 2 years, the Government has introduced temporary measures to assist wool growers who, because of the drought, advanced shearing dates during the 1964-65 and 1965-66 income years. When this occurred, the proceeds of two wool clips would have been brought to account for taxation purposes in the 1 year. Provision was therefore made for these wool growers to elect to transfer the net proceeds of the second clip to the succeeding income year so that these proceeds were taxed in the year in which they would ordinarily have been received. It is proposed to continue the operation of these provisions for the 1966-67 income year and subsequent years, and to extend them also to advanced shearings brought about by fire or flood.

The Bill also proposes the continuation, without any limit as to lime, of the special 20% depreciation allowances on plant and structural improvements used for primary production purposes. The final amendment proposed by the Bill is the allowance of an outright deduction in the year of incurrence for the full cost of subdivisional fencing erected on land used in primary production. At present, this fencing is generally subject to annual depreciation allowances at the special rate of 20% per annum. Boundary fences or fences around stockyards are not included in the proposal but will remain subject to depreciation allowances. The amendment will apply to expenditure incurred on subdivisional fencing during the 1967-68 income year and subsequent years. More detailed explanations of the Bill are contained in explanatory notes which are being made available to honourable senators and I do not propose to speak at greater length on the Bill at this stage.I commend it to honourable senators.

speech.para: The Bill now before honourable senators proposes amendments to the Schedule to the Excise Tariff 1921-1967. The purpose is to enact, as from 17th March 1957, increased rates of duty on canned fruit. On the recommendation of the Australian Canned Fruits Board the rates of excise duty on canned apricots, peaches, pears and mixtures thereof are increased from 20c to 30c per dozen 29-oz cans - this is the basic con tainer size - with equivalent increases on other can sizes. It will be recalled that when the Government introduced amending legislation in 1963 to reconstitute the Australian Canned Fruits Board, it agreed to impose an excise duty on canned deciduous fruits entered for consumption within Australia so as to providethe Board with additional funds to assist the industry in developing markets for the greatly increased supplies of fruit that had become available. The proposal advanced by the industry at the time and accepted by the Government was that the maximum rate of excise duty that could be imposed would be 60c per dozen 29-oz cans with the operative rate from time to time within this ceiling to be decided on the recommendation of the Board. This proposal has the substantial support of canners and growers.

The previous rate of 20c per dozen 29-oz cans yielded about $1.2m a year. This money is expended by the Board in exercising its functions under the provisions of the Canned Fruits Export Marketing Act 1963-1966 'to encourage, assist and promote the exportation of canned fruits from Australia and the consumption and sale outside Australia'.

Over recent years there has been a large increase in the availability of canned deciduous fruits for export. Production increased from 7.3 million cartons in 1963 to an estimated 10.5 million cartons in 1967 and it is expected that the availability of fruit for canning from existing plantings will continue to grow. Home consumption accounts for about 3 million cartons a year, which means that at present pack levels about 7.5 million cartons are available for export yearly. In 1966 there was a record movement of 6.6 million cartons to overseas markets but even so the stock carryover assumed a relatively high level of 2 million cartons. Our main competitor, South Africa, is also increasing production at a fairly fast rate and has now taken over as the leading supplier in the major United Kingdom market.

The funds obtained from the excise duty have enabled the industry to obtain some foothold in the major markets on the continent of Europe, particularly in Germany, where the sales level has risen from a nominal level in 1963 to about 800,000 cartons last year. The Board has also been able to intensify promotional activity in Canada with a corresponding increase in trade from 150,000 cartons in 1963 to 700,000 cartons in 1966.

The Board, backed by canning interests representing a substantial proportion of production, and the central growers organisation - the Australian Canning Fruitgrowers Association - has sought the increases in duty now proposed so that additional funds will be provided for the further developmental work needed to move the increased supplies of fruit cur- rently available. The Government is fully seised of the need to give all reasonable assistance to the Board and the industry in their efforts not only to consolidate but to expand all possible overseas outlets for our canned deciduous fruits. It agrees that the Board will require additional revenue for the purpose at this stage. Accordingly it has been pleased to accept the Board's recommendation which, at present home consumption levels, will provide an additional $600,000 in a full year. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
