The honourable senator also referred to the appropriation for advertising in Division No. 645 - Recruiting Campaign. Senator Wright also referred to that appropriation. I am afraid I do not have a breakup of the expenditure on advertising as between newspapers, radio and television. I cannot give the honourable senator that information. I am told that it is flexible and changes every year. An indication of how it was spent last year might be of some value, but I am afraid I cannot give it.

asked about the results obtained from the expenditure on advertising. I can give him only the recruiting figures for the Services for 1966-67. For the Navy there were 8,920 applications for enlistment; for the Army 12,673 applications; and for the Air Force 7,350 applications. I cannot tell him, nor do I believe that anybody else can tell him, how many of these applications would have been made if there had been no advertising and how many of them are attributable to advertising. As has always been the case, the number of acceptances was much lower than the number of applications. This is because some applicants failed to measure up to medical and educational requirements, and so on. In 1966-67, enlistments in the Navy totalled 2,364; in the Army, they numbered 3,292 and in the Air Force 2,279. That is the end result of our efforts to recruit people to our three Services.

speech.para: I have no doubt whatever that those figures would drop considerably if advertising were not engaged in, but 1 could not attempt to estimate the degree to which they would drop. I think all fair-minded senators will agree that the standard of advertising for recruitment in Australia is very good. The Press advertising, of course, one just reads, but the radio and, more particularly, the television advertising, has always impressed me as an individual as being a very good type of advertising very well carried out. That is all I can say. I could do no more than estimate - and my estimate would be no better than anybody else's - what part of the final result was due to advertising or what the result, would have been if there had been no advertising.

talk.start.para: - I wish to draw the Minister's attention to the amount spent on the recruiting campaign over the past 5 or 6 years. I should like him or his officers to explain why it is that about the same figure has been expended each year on advertising. The amount to be appropriated this year is $1.3m, and that has been about the average figure expended in each of the past 5 or 6 years. I emphasise that this figure was the amount expended on advertising during the years before the introduction of the compulsory call-up under the national service training scheme. I remember that in those days the Government was seeking to attract volunteers to the reserves, and Senator Paltridge practically admitted that the recruiting campaign seeking to attract volunteers was a failure.
- He did admit failure.

- It was because of this that the Government introduced the national service training scheme under which men are called up compulsorily. Because enlistment is compulsory the need for expenditure on advertising should disappear and I emphasise that the national service trainees now comprise approximately 90% of our Army personnel. I would have thought that with the introduction of compulsory national service training the cost of obtaining a full complement of troops for Vietnam would be cut considerably. But it has remained at much the same figure. I should like to know why the Department has not been able to cut the cost of advertising by at least 50%. I have made many inquiries into this matter, and I am convinced that the Government has not been really interested in volunteers over the last 5 or 6 years but has been working more towards full reliance upon the national service training scheme. Despite this, the advertising costs have remained the same. I would like an explanation of this, if there is one.
- In addition to what the honourable senator says about advertising costs remaining the same, the advertising media used have been extended. Television is used extensively.

- That is so. The Minister said in reply to Senator Wright that he should not be expected to be able to produce figures showing the amount of expenditure incurred in obtaining a given number of recruits. I would say that any properly organised efficient advertising department would be able to do that. With modern advertising of such things as foodstuffs or other commodities the agents can produce accurate figures as to the results obtained from advertising campaigns. I am surprised to hear the Minister say that the officers of the Department of the Army cannot give him some indication of the enlistment results from a given expenditure.

speech.para: I have been watching this position over the years. I have seen that the amount appropriated has remained constant. I repeat that I would have thought that with the introduction of national service training, for which no advertising is needed, the cost of the recruiting campaign would have been cut by at least half. The appropriation for this year for the whole of Division No. 645 is $1,573,500, and we are just about to call up another group of men. I should think that these men will be called up under the national service scheme which requires no expenditure on advertising. This appears to me to be a case of very loose accounting and I would like an explanation from the Minister.

talk.start.para: - I refer first to Division No. 645, subdivision 2, item 04, which relates to advertising. Can the Minister tell me the method by which the Defence Department carries out its advertising? Is it done through private organisations, or does the Department do its own advertising? If contracts are let to private organisations, can the Minister explain the manner in which contracts are arranged? I also have the same interest as other honourable senators in obtaining a clarification of the almost constant appropriation of $1.3m over the years for advertising costs.

speech.para: I refer now to Division No. 640, subdivision 2, item 05, which relates to the hire and maintenance of plant and equipment. The appropriation for this item is $335,300 and the amount actually expended last year was $250,248. What is it within the defence complex that we are hiring today? One would imagine that it would be office equipment or automatic data processing equipment, but I thought that the defence Services had equipment of this type of their own.

I come now to defence Services generally, and what I have said with relation to the Department of Defence applies also here. Although the total allocation for Defences Services is approximately $662m I am concerned about the proposed expenditure of almost $18m, an enormous sum of money, by the Department of Defence. I think the people generally are reluctant to take too much notice of the accuracy of expenditure in this direction. I have read with interest comments which the AuditorGeneral has made and one would be inclined to hold the view that the people believe that there should not be too much investigation into expenditure in the various areas of defence. This perhaps is reflected in insufficient control being exercised by those persons who have been given the job of controlling accounting procedures within this and other defence Services.

talk.start.para: - Is the honourable senator referring to any division in particular?

- Perhaps I could say Division No. 640. I was speaking generally in relation to the Department of Defence because the Auditor-General's comments on the whole defence area indicate in this year 1967 some carelessness in the control of accounting whether it be within Australia or overseas. One probably could instance many occasions on which the AuditorGeneral has had occasion to say either that an internal audit is insufficient or that the control of financing, even in relation to some of our overseas contracts, is entirely insufficient. I hope that the AuditorGeneral, in his report next year, will not have cause to comment about overpayments or insufficient control in accounting procedures in the defence Services.

speech.para: Mention was made earlier today of the difficulty servicemen in Vietnam are experiencing in obtaining postage stamps. Perhaps my remarks are not related directly to the Department of Defence; I merely say that I understand that during the last war no postage was charged on mail from servicemen overseas. I advocate a similar practice at this time.

talk.start.para: - Senator Webster asked how the Commonwealth runs its advertising campaigns. There is in existence an organisation known as the Commonwealth Advisory Council on Advertising or the Commonwealth Advertising Council, I am not sure which, consisting of representatives of the big advertising companies in Australia who provide their services free to the Department of Defence to advise on the layout of advertisements, the general planning of advertising campaigns and so on.
- Persons not connected with advertising media, I hope.

- I am advised that some of them do control media of their own but they are- not connected with broadcasting stations. I may have to amplify that statement later. Nevertheless, I believe there is no financial advantage to those people. I was asked about the hire and maintenance of plant and equipment. The honourable senator was correct; most of it is office equipment. Some $76,000 is provided to cover the cost of the hire of office machines, the cost of computer processing of overseas data and the maintenance of office machines for the Defence Cataloguing Authority, and there is allocation of $4,900 to meet the cost of recurring maintenance on office machines. Tn the electronic data processing group $139,000 is provided for the maintenance of computer equipment, $18,000 for the maintenance of flexowriters, tape certification equipment and miscellaneous machines and equipment, as well as $8,000 for shop repairs.

speech.para: In the Joint Intelligence Division provision is made for $3,400 for the maintenance of miscellaneous office machines, and in the Defence Signals Division there is an allocation of $36,000 for the hire of punch card equipment; an allocation of $34,000 for replacement parts and the modification, repair and maintenance of machines; an allocation of $10,000 for spares for computer and air conditioning maintenance, and an allocation of $6,000 for tools and workshop necessities including expendable materials for maintenance. The bulk of this expenditure is for maintenance although the hire of some punch card equipment and some office machines is also included.

I think the last matter the honourable senator raised related to accounting procedures and, in particular, to overpayments which have been criticised by the AuditorGeneral. My recollection - I think it is cor rect - is that those criticisms were directed against Treasury accountants overseas, particularly in the United States, who had made mistakes of that kind, rather than against any internal audit accountants of the Department of Defence. I think that is what the honourable senator has in his mind. Indeed, I think this matter is engaging the attention of the Public Accounts Committee which is now talking to Mr Harris, a Treasury official concerned with this aspect. Senator Ormonde said that he thought the advertising appropriation should be cut.

talk.start.para: - On account of the reduced need for Army recruitment.

- That is the impression I gained. He believed the advertising appropriation should be cut because national service is providing a number of servicemen. This is a rather different attitude from that of Senator McClelland who said he thought the appropriation should be increased. To Senator Ormonde I say that the Army is calling up compulsorily more people, but the Army is not the only Service with which we are concerned. The Navy is made up entirely of volunteers who have signed on for long terms. So is the Air Force. Those Services have expanded considerably. I think the Navy now is twice the size it was, in relation to manpower, when I was Minister for the Navy. The Air Force has also expanded. However, u remains true that the Army cannot be built on short term national service trainees. There must be a constant and growing core of long term regular soldiers to provide the nucleus to keep the whole thing going. We need 10,500 volunteers in this- current year for this purpose. As the number of short term national service trainees grows, there is a requirement for an increase in the regular component of the Army.

speech.para: I do not think the other point Senator Ormonde raised is quite valid. 1 know that a company can expend a certain amount of money on advertising toothpaste and can say: 'As a result of our expenditure on the advertising campaign in this district our sales have increased to this extent'. Maybe that can be worked out. Expenditure on advertising may be an allowable deduction for income tax purposes. There may be some incentive to spend money on advertising for that reason. Maybe advertising agents are pretty good at selling things. Any way, eventually this kind of judgment is made. But I do not think that can be done in this field. Nor do I think - 'and I come now to Senator McClelland's suggestion - that it is necessarily wise to expand considerably in this area. 1 believe that what is needed is a fairly constant, steady level of advertising to keep the requirements before the public. If we try to saturate the market or to increase the advertising by, say, 50%, the extra return that we would or would not obtain from that is a matter of judgment. But it k not a matter of judgment - or, if it is, it is a judgment with which I agree - that we need to maintain fairly constant level of advertising of the opportunities in the Army, the Navy and the Air Force. We certainly should not let our advertising drop below that level.

talk.start.para: - I did not intend to speak at all on this section of the Estimates but after listening to some of the evasive answers given by the Minister I feel impelled to ask questions too. The appropriation for office requisites and equipment, stationery and printing under Division No. 640 shows a tremendous increase over the expenditure last year. Whilst somebody is in touch with the position, 1 do not think the Minister's answer to a previous question about this item was complete. Last financial year the expenditure on this item was $289,962. This year the appropriation has been increased to $367,400. That is quite a substantial increase. We should be given more details of how that great increase has been brought about. I do not want to hear the excuse that it is .caused by increases in wages and salaries, or something like that. That is a favourite Government excuse for increases in expenditure which are not always brought about by that factor.

speech.para: I also refer to the appropriation for the hire and maintenance of plant and equipment. Senator Webster, who has now left the chamber, asked questions about this item. The Minister gave some figures which covered only part of the total appropriation. Those figures might have satisfied Senator Webster but they do not satisfy me. Unless I did not hear the Minister correctly, he said that advertising agents in

Australia were providing free advertising out of their patriotic hearts. If the Government is receiving free services, I say that it should do the same as industry does and pay the appropriate fee for the service that is rendered, whatever it may be. If the Government did that we might have decent advertising. Perhaps the reason why the Government has fallen down in this field is that it is getting second rate advertisers to do the job for it. It is obvious that the advertising is false.

Many youngsters in the Navy have told me at various times that they were carried away by the deceptiveness of the advertising for the Navy. The advertisments say: 'Join the Navy and see the world'. But these youngsters finish up on some land base, peeling spuds in the kitchen. A similar situation exists in the Army. Its advertising says: 'Join the Army and learn a trade'. But half of the men who go into the Army are unable to cope with the civilian world when they come out at the end of their period of training because they have not learnt a trade. Their parents were tricked into letting them join that arm of the Services. This may be put down to deceptive advertising.

The Air Force advertising says: 'Join the Air Force and be a pilot'. But the number of youngsters who are finally selected as pilots is only a fraction of the number who join the Air Force with a spirit of adventure motivating them. If they are really unlucky, they will finish up as Mirage pilots and be killed anyway.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - They may fly VIP aircraft.

- They might be killed in VIP aircraft. Only the best pilots are selected for those aircraft, in spite of the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt) tells us that they are used for training purposes. A fellow cannot fly a VIP aircraft and eat pie in the sky and sausage rolls unless he is an expert pilot. 1 refer now to the appropriation for medical fees in Division No. 645. Last year the expenditure was $82,013. This year the appropriation is $86,000. Who receives these medical fees? Do they go to private practitioners? Do they go to general hospitals? In respect of whom are these medical fees paid? Are they national service trainees? Are they members of the Citizen Military Forces? Are these fees for medical inspections of recruits or merely of some of the aged recruiting officers whom the Services have and who need extra medical attention?

speech.para: I wish to make one point in respect of the appropriation for advertising. Although the Government indulges in half page and full page advertisements in the metropolitan Press and to a greater degree in advertisements on metropolitan television stations, in the area from which I come - north Queensland - we hardly ever see a recruiting advertisement. According to the records, Queensland in general and Queensland country districts in particular supply more recruits for some of the Services than do other parts of the Commonwealth with comparable populations. Is that because Queensland is plagued with unemployment from time to time? Does the Government believe that it does not need to advertise in Queensland, particularly in the country areas, because in those areas, as a result of the seasonal nature of employment, most of the young people find themselves in dead end labouring occupations, are unable to make their way in civilian life and therefore are forced to enter one of the Services in order to earn an ordinary living. I have made those points because I was provoked into doing so by the Minister fobbing everybody off. In other words, he gave other honourable senators only enough information to keep them quiet. I am surprised at his doing that only two days after his elevation to the position of Leader of the Government in the Senate.

talk.start.para: - I do not think I will comment on Senator Keeffe's remarks about fobbing off questioners. I have been trying to give them the information for which they have asked. As this answer proceeds, if Senator Keeffe has any decency, I think he will withdraw what he has just said about the way in which I have been answering questions. He may or may not do that.
- What was it that offended the Minister?

- I was referring to the honourable senator's statement that I had been fobbing off questioners and not giving them sufficient information. He said that I did not give Senator Webster information covering the question that he asked. I am not particularly offended. 1 am just making the point that what Senator Keeffe said is untrue.
- I added up the figures as the Minister gave them.

- I will give them again. Senator Keeffe asked me about the appropriation for office requisites and equipment, stationery and printing under Division No. 640. He asked for an explanation of the increase of about $77,000 in the appropriation for that item. This year's appropriation is to be spent as follows: On the purchase of overseas item indent data, books, materials for reproducing forms and punch cards, printing the Defence Manual and copy-strip materials for the Defence Cataloguing Authority, $82,500; on general stationery requirements, $57,200; on the printing of the Defence Report and other pamphlets and books, $7,500; on stationery requirements at overseas posts, $5,000; on the purchase of security stationery and the purchase and maintenance of safes and combination locks, $2,000; on the purchase of books, maps and papers, $2,000; on the purchase of office machines, $1,000; and on the printing and special stationery requirements for industrial mobilisation courses, $700. The total of those figures is $157,900. Dealing with electronic data processing, an amount of $69,000 Ls set aside for special stationery including magnetic and paper tape. An amount of $7,500 is provided for special printing and reproduction services. For books for branch use the sum of $4,000 is provided and $1,500 is provided for office machines. This gives a total for electronic data processing of $82,000.

speech.para: Tn the Joint Intelligence Division the sum of $8,560 is provided for miscellaneous general stationery and office requisites. An amount of $3,000 is provided for a Xerox copying machine.- For photographic supplies the sum of $2,500 is provided. An amount of $640 is provided for office machines. For covers and binders $2,000 is provided and $10,800 for books, maps and papers. This gives a total for the Joint Intelligence Division of $27,500.

In the Defence Signals Division the sum of $24,000 is provided for office stationery. printing and binding. The sum of $40,600 is provided for communications stationery. For special machine requirements $36,000 is provided; $2,000 for office equipment and $1,400 for books and maps. This gives a total of $104,000, but there is an amount of $4,000 which is recoverable, giving a total for the Defence Signals Division of $100,000. The total under item 02 is $367,400. The increase of $77,438 over last year's expenditure is sought in order to provide $48,696 for additional overseas data for the Defence Cataloguing Authority, $16,090 for increased requirements for executive staff, and $13,479 for the purchase of magnetic tapes for electronic data processing in order to return tapes at present on loan from the Services. There is also a minor increase of $1,190 which balances with the decrease in the Joint Intelligence Division.

talk.start.para: - That is much better.

- No, it is precisely the same. I now move to item 05, which Senator Webster also asked about. At the risk of wearying the Senate I repeat what I said to Senator Webster. I will give the full figures as I did to Senator Webster.
- I do not think it is necessary to have them again.
- 1 asked the question, not Senator Webster.

- I do not think I should weary the Senate with these figures. Despite what Senator Keeffe has alleged, 1 did give the full information. Let me run through it again. For the Executive the sum of $76,000 is provided for hire of office machines, cost of computer processing of overseas data and maintenance of office machines for the Defence Cataloguing Authority. The sum of $4,900 is provided for recurring maintenance of office machines. This gives a total for the Executive of $80,900. For electronic data processing, the sum of $139,000 is provided for maintenance of computer equipment, $18,000 for maintenance of flexowriters, tape certification equipment and miscellaneous machines and equipment, and $8,000 for shop repairs, giving a total of $165,000. For the Joint Intelligence Division the sum of $3,400 is provided for maintenance of miscellaneous office machines. In the Defence Signals Division $36,000 is provided for the hire of punched card equipment, $34,000 for replacement parts, modification, repair and maintenance of machines, $10,000 for spares for computer and air conditioning maintenance, and $6,000 for tools and workshop necessities including expendable materials for maintenance, giving a total of $86,000. This gives a grand total for item 05 of $335,300. 1 do not think Senator Keeffe was justified in claiming that information had been withheld on this matter. Senator Keeffe also referred to the proposed expenditure of $86,000 under Division No. 645, subdivision 2, item 03. This refers to expenditure on medical fees. The item provides for the payment of fees to medical practitioners for the medical examination of volunteers for the Permanent and Citizen Forces. They are civilian doctors and there is a set scale of fees laid down by the Treasury. The increase this year is due to an increase in the scale of fees and because of the fact that, where necessary, recruits are sent to specialists whereas formerly this type of examination was carried out by the Services. If a man goes to a general practitioner for a medical examination for recruitment and it is thought that he has something wrong with an ear or an eye requiring the opinion of a specialist, that man would be sent to a specialist and the vote for the Department of Defence would meet the specialist's fee. Formerly the Service vote would have met the fee.
- Who are the advertising agents who do the work for nothing?

- I did not say that advertisements were inserted in media free of charge. I said that an advertising council was formed to give advice free of charge to the Department of Defence concerning the medium to use and the layout of advertisements. Nobody has ever said that the hiring of newspaper space or the drawing up of advertisements was free of charge. The council of advertising firms gives advice to the Government on the best method of conducting its campaign. This is done without fee. Our advertising is in newspapers, periodicals, on the radio and on television. None of these media is owned by members of the advertising council which gives advice to the Government. Those members are advertising experts who use media owned by other people. They are advertising agents; advertising firms. They do not own television stations, radio stations or newspapers. The radio stations, television stations and newspapers charge the same rates as they would charge anybody else advertising. The advice is given by people who do not own the media and therefore they do not get a rake off because the Government uses a particular media.

- I refer to Division No. 652 which deals with defence aid for Malaysia and Singapore. 1 imagine that the provision under this Division is a reflection of the statement in the Budget that $6. 2 86m would be given to Malaysia and Singapore for defence aid. Expenditure last year under this heading amounted to $8,036,462, the amount appropriated being $8.235m. Will the Minister say why so much less is being sought this year than was sought or spent, last year? Having regard to the recent statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt) on Britain's withdrawal from this part of the world it does not seem realistic to be reducing our expenditure on defence aid in this region. However, there may be provisions under other headings to take care of any future programme on defence which the Australian Government may have in mind in the light of changed international events and new pressures and emergencies that might arise. i turn now to Division No. 655 - Other

speech.para: Administrations - Recoverable Expenditure. Under sub-division 1, item 01 in respect of the United States of America this year an amount of just over $lm is sought, less a certain amount to be recovered, making a total for Division No. 655 of $254,000. This compares with a credit last year of $257,000, which is very close to the amount of $254,000. I am interested in some of the detail in this factor. At the Minister's convenience I should appreciate some explanation of what is involved in this expenditure for which some amount is recovered. My prime interest at this stage is in relation to defence aid for Malaysia and Singapore and the reasons for the decline in the amount.

talk.start.para: - Once again I refer to Division No. 645 and hark back to the recruiting campaign. The Minister will recall that when I first spoke on this subject 1 directed his attention to the item relating to community survey for which the expenditure last year was $7,000 but for which there is no appropriation this year. I am interested to know whether that community survey was concerned with the effectiveness or otherwise of the general recruiting campaign which has been conducted by the Department over the years. I pointed out to the Minister that compared with the cost of surveys which are conducted by private organisations an expenditure of $7,000 for the purpose of measuring the effectiveness of the recruiting campaign would be a mere drop in the bucket. But having heard what the Minister said about recruiting generally it occurred to me that the Government and the Department seem to be treating this item as merely a necessary evil instead of trying in some effective way to conduct a planned recruiting campaign or one which is an improvement on the present campaign. I have reached this conclusion as a result of information supplied to me this evening by the Minister in addition to other information which appears in the Estimates.

speech.para: What Senator Ormonde said about the amount of expenditure on recruiting activities having been static over the years is quite true. As far back as 1964 the total amount spent on recruiting campaigns in one financial year was $1,296,000. according to an answer supplied to me in November 1964. In other words, 3 years ago the allocation was exactly the same as it is today, despite cost increases and the extension of communication services, particularly television. I am rather surprised that the Department has been unable to supply a breakdown of the expenditure involved in recruiting activities so that we could know how much has been spent on advertising in the Press, on radio and on television. I should have thought that in compiling the Estimates for this financial year an estimate would have been made of the amount that would have been spent on newspaper advertising, the amount that would have been spent on broadcasting and the amount that would have been spent on television. I would have expected information to be available so that we could know whether the expenditure was in capital cities or in country areas.

In November 1964 the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Beaton) directed a question to the Minister or Defence on this subject. At that time in an answer to the honourable member the Minister for Defence supplied details of expenditure on advertising in the Press and on radio and television for all branches of the armed Services, separate amounts being shown for the Army, the Navy and the Air Force. I should have thought that if the information was available then it should be available now. After supplying that information in November 1964 the Minister went on to say that it was not possible at that stage to give precise figures so far as country stations were concerned but that arrangements had been made to advertise on country television stations in the following year. That would have been in 1965. He went on to say that in other respects expenditure would broadly follow the general pattern of the previous year. Bearing in mind the great expansion of television services that has occurred throughout Australia in the last 4 years I should have thought that the expenditure involved would have been much greater and the techniques used would have been quite different.

The Minister has told us that an advertising council has been formed, that the council is composed of representatives of advertising firms who give advice to the Services on the layout of advertisements to be used. But I wonder whether any advice is given as to the newspapers in which the advertisements are to be inserted, the radio stations over which they will be broadcast and the television stations on which the tele-recordings will appear. Surely one of the first things that any person involved in advertising would try to assess would be a measurement of prospective readers and audiences. Advertising companies spend probably millions of dollars on surveys of this nature. Commercial television stations pay out great sums of money for the McNair and Anderson surveys which are conducted from time to time. Bearing in mind the importance of recruiting today I am rather surprised that the Department has no experts of its own rather than rely on outside people for this advice. As I have said, I cannot help thinking that the Government adopts an attitude of this kind towards this expenditure: I suppose we have to spend some money on advertising for recruits; otherwise we might be accused of not wanting them.

It is rather significant that the expenditure on advertising in the last financial year was only $291 less than the amount appropriated. Perhaps I am wrong, but it seems to mc that expenditure reached the amount appropriated at a certain point during the year and the Department then said : 'We now have to cut out advertising because the vote for this item has practically run out.' I suggest that the Department must look closely at this matter and consider whether a planned and more effective technique can be brought into the recruiting campaign to achieve better results in the interests of this country's defence.

talk.start.para: - I propose to refer to two or three matters. Senator Davidson mentioned Division No. 652 which relates to defence aid for Malaysia and Singapore. The expenditure proposed for this year is less than the expenditure incurred last year. The honourable senator will recall that a 3-year programme was agreed to in which S25m was to be made available for defence aid for Malaysia and Singapore. The vote of S6m this years is the balance of that $25m. The Government announced a few days ago a new programme of aid over the next 3 years which will involve an expenditure of $16m for Malaysia and $4m for Singapore. However, the expenditure on that new programme will not begin until next financial year. The exact requirements of that programme are now being discussed with the authorities in Malaysia and Singapore. Before I come to the other matter raised by Senator Davidson in relation to Division No. 655 which refers to other administrations, recoverable expenditure, T should like to deal with division No. 645, sub-division 2, item 05, Community Survey' which was mentioned by Senator McClelland. The honourable senator asked why no amount is provided this year for this item.
- And what tha survey was last year.

- The community survey was carried out over a period of U months extending over 2 financial years. Expenditure on this survey was finalised in the last financial year, the total expenditure being $36,000. A certain amount was provided in the previous year's vote, $7,000 being provided in last vear s vote.

speech.para: The survey was carried out to make a report on the community's attitude to the Defence Services. The report was completed and has been presented to the Minister. The matter is therefore finalised.

Moving on to Division No. 655 - Other Administrations - Recoverable Expenditure, 1 think that the best thing I can do is to give to Senator Davidson the information contained in a note which 1 have. The item provides for expenditure on a pre-payment basis on transactions on behalf of the Advanced Research Projects Agency, which is a civilian agency of the United States Department of Defense. The transactions involved are for services performed by Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities in connection with the construction and operation of the Joint United StatesAustralian Defence Based Research Facility at Alice Springs. Provision has been made for freight and handling charges, vehicle hire expenses, Postmaster-General's services, road construction and rental of accommodation. That is the expenditure. We expect the estimated receipts from the United States to be based on planned transactions under sub-division 1 less a credit of $257,046 standing in the United States account at 1st July 1967.

talk.start.para: - Very briefly 1 would like to refer to Division No. 640, sub-division 2, item 05, which deals with the hire and maintenance of plant and equipment. The proposed appropriation for 1967-68 is not a substantial amount, but it is an increase of approximately $80,000, or 331%, on the expenditure for 1966-67. I should have thought that by this stage the Army would not bc hiring much equipment. I should like to know the type of plant and equipment which is being hired.

speech.para: Secondly I refer to the provision for postage, telegrams and telephone services under Division No. 645. Here the situation seems to be the reverse. The proposed appropriation for 1967-68 is $22,500 as against an expenditure of $20,311 for 1966-67.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - They are working on the old rates.

- I do not care whether or not they are the old rates. In view of the increase in the recruiting cam- paign I am wondering whether the amount provided is sufficient to meet the demand. I intended to ask a question about Division No. 655, but the Minister has just answered a question asked by Senator Davidson in relation to that matter. I understand that the proposed provision refers to the Advanced Research Projects Agency in Alice Springs. My final query relates to Division No. 661 - Buildings. Works, Fittings and Furniture. talk.start.para: I refer to Division No. 640 - Administrative. I should like the Minister to tell me, if possible, how far the review concerning the unification of the three Services has gone. Even before I entered the Federal Parliament 1 said that it was time we abolished the three Services as such and combined them. I know that this would horrify the civil servants. At the present time there are 14,000 civil servants catering for the needs of approximately 83,000 members of the permanent forces. It must be very gratifying to the personnel of the permanent forces to know that for every six of them there is one civil servant behind them looking after their needs. Australia cannot afford this. If other countries can do with one department administering the three Services, so can Australia. To me it is quite absurd that in a small country such as Australia we should have the head of the Department of Defence receiving $17,500 per annum and the heads of three other defence departments receiving $15,000 per annum, together with hosts of Deputy Secretaries and First Assistant Secretaries. I think I quickly counted 20 highly paid officers in the Department of Defence and 23 in the Department of the Navy, the Department of the Army and the Department of Air. Most of them could be eliminated with the unification of the three Services. Later on, when dealing with a different Division, 1 shall mention that the medical services should be combined. Apart from the savings that would ensure, at least we would get rid of three Ministers.

- In reply to Senator Turnbull, I can only say that I do not know of any review which is going on. I may be misinformed. I may not have all the information that I should have. I do not know of a review which is directed, as a matter of policy, to the unification of the three Services. I am bound to say that I think it would be a very retrograde step if the three Services were to be combined; I do not believe that the arrangement would work well at all. I agree with Senator Turnbull on one point. There are elements of the Services which I think could well be unified; the medical services appear to me to be a case in point. It is a matter of judgment and of debate. I do not believe that it would result in considerable savings in the number of public servants employed. 1 do not believe that the Parliament would be as well served if it had one Minister trying to answer questions for all four departments. I do not believe that the Services themselves would be as efficient or effective. But there is a great volume of opinion on the other side. However, this is not a matter in "relation to which we are at present seeking an appropriation.

Senator ORMONDE(New South Wales) (10.37] - There has been some mention of the recruiting campaign this evening, and I am concerned to see that we get value for the money .that we spend on advertising in this campaign. I ask the Minister whether anything has been done to obviate the obvious waste of money and effort in calling for volunteers for the Army, the Navy and the Air Force and then rejecting a large proportion of them. One report that I read stated that one in every two applicants ls rejected for educational reasons. The inquiries that I have made lead me to believe that that assessment is correct. This high rejection rate represents a good deal of wasted effort and money, merely because of educational deficiencies. Has the Government considered establishing some educational service that can improve the educational standards of volunteers and thereby enable them to be recruited to the Services after they have attained the required educational standards? I believe that the standards set are not especially high and that some of the rejections are due to quite elementary deficiencies. In World War II, the Army had an educational service under which the recruiting section conducted training schools that helped to make up the leeway. Is there any such organisation at present to make it possible to recruit volunteers who would otherwise be rejected because they cannot cope with arithmetic or perhaps English at elementary levels? I have heard it said in this chamber that the modern soldier needs higher educational qualifications than those that were required of soldiers during the last war. Is anything being done in that regard and has it been possible to rescue - if I might use the word - any of the applicants who want to join the Army but have not the necessary educational qualifications?

speech.para: Two other matters raised are not directly related to a particular appropriation in the Estimates. I do not believe that discussions which take place between outside industriesand the defence forces are concerned with the education of people who apply to join the Services but are found to fall below the educational standard. The standard required is much lower than the Leaving standard. The discussions have been more concerned with industrial mobilisation of machinery and manpower, and that type of subject.

It is not easy for young men to become apprentices in any of the Services and to gain entry to the Navy's Nirimba college, the college run by the Army, or the college, at Wagga run by the Air Force. talk.start.para: - I wish to relate my remarks to Division No. 348 - Forestry and Timber Bureau. debateinfo.title: RESOLUTIONS CARRIED AT CONFERENCE TOWARDS MAXIMUM ABILITY TO CONTROL WILDFIRE

item.para: Since high intensity wildfire is a national disaster in terms of both money and life, national wealth should contribute to its prevention and suppression.

debate.para: This conference recommends the Commonwealth Government consider setting up a professional fire-fighting service to supplement existing bush fire organisations in Australian States.

Such » service should be highly mobile with appropriate modern equipment and should move from Stale to Slate, including Tasmania, in accordance with the progression of the fire season and the occurrence of fires. lt is believed such a system would provide continuous usage of highly trained fire-fighting personnel and sophisticated equipment, whereas existing local forces, because of limited local fire seasons and voluntary membership, cannot be expected to possess the most effective equipment.

This service should not supersede existing fire services but should be used for immediate attack on major fires and particularly (ires difficult of access, in co-operation with local brigades. Equipment should include both fixed (s.t.o.l.) and rotary wing aircraft to be used for -

item.para: fire detection;
aerial ignition by prescribed burning;
reconnaissance and mapping;
attacks on small or slow tires in areas difficult of access;
mopping up; and
transport of personnel and supplies.
lt is agreed that all wildfire should be suppressed. Reduction of fuel availability seems to be the most practical means yet devised of preventing the occurrence of large high intensity fires.

debate.para: Prescribed burning, properly executed, seems to be a means of accomplishing this economically over large areas. Aerial ignition under suitable circumstances would extend the scope of this. Prescribed burning is unacceptable in certain areas for a variety of reasons. Under these circumstances, an alternative method of fuel reduction should be considered, e.g. hand-raking, slashing, filtering, etc. When fuel reduction is not carried out, management plans should ensure that fire cannot escape from area.

item.para: This conference urges all appropriate State government departments and all State National Park authorities (Lands, Agriculture, Forestry, Scenery Preservation Board) to make fullest possible use of aircraft both fixed and rotary in detection and suppression of bush fires -
Fire detection;
Aerial ignition by prescribed burning;
Reconnaissance and mapping;
Attack small or slow fires in areas difficult of access;
Mopping up; and
Transport of personnel and supplies. -

debate.para: Recently the Minister for National Development (Mr Fairbairn) assumed the title of Chairman of the Australian Forestry Council. Senator O'Byrne and I attended the conference held in Canberra on bush fire prevention. It will be seen from the list of resolutions carried at the conference that considerable attention was paid to the use of aircraft in bush fire prevention, not only for conventional purposes, but also for spotting and many kindred purposes. I raised this subject during the debate on legislation covering softwood plantings as well as the debate on the estimates of the CSIRO. Reports on the use of aircraft in fire fighting have appeared in the Press but the details given have been rather sketchy.

I ask the Minister for Supply (Senator Henty), who represents the Minister for National Development in this chamber, to inform the Senate of the results of visits to North America by some of our forestry experts to procure certain aircraft. I refer to the Canadian aircraft for use as water bombers, for the dropping of chemical bombs or for other purposes. Members of the Opposition think that the Department of National Development should step up considerably the use of aircraft in fire fighting. We go further than that, as will be seen from the list of resolutions I have incorporated in Hansard-. We believe that the Commonwealth should create a national fire fighting squad. Since this matter was raised I have obtained from the Treasurer (Mr McMahon) details of the amounts expended over the last 10 years on bush fire relief. It amounts to many millions of dollars. I think that at present the Government is budgeting for the expenditure of about $8m more as a result of the terrible Tasmanian bush fires.

I would like to get from the Minister in reply to my suggestion about a national fire fighting force more than a comment on what it would cost. If the cost of such a squad - it would be fairly large - is offset against the cost of bush fire relief, it is obvious that there is a reasonable financial margin. Greater use could- be made of more modern detection methods to supplement the activities undertaken at State level.

I refer now to Division No. 345 - Bureau of Mineral Resources. Senator Henty will recall that recently I pointed out to him very forcibly that it seems fruitless that top flight officers in the Bureau should point out to the States the locations of deposits of limestone and other minerals while the States adopt an offhanded attitude and do not act on the suggestions made to them. I would like an assurance from the Minister that when research and surveys are undertaken by the Commonwealth, the Minister for National Development or his officers will confer with the State Ministers for Mines. Recently in a debate on the adjournment of the Senate I referred to tremendous agitation at the failure of the New South Wales Minister for Mines to make a definite decision on whether to give some combines approval to ravish the Blue Mountains area of New South Wales. The Department of National Development could furnish first class advice as to alternative sites for the operations of the combines. I do urge the Minister to do what he can to ensure that rather than pander to the cement combines the States will accept the advice of the Bureau of Mineral Resources based on surveys. I know that Senator Henty agrees with me on this matter, for he knows that at one stage there was talk of disregarding section 92 of the Constitution.

I come now to Division 342, and remind the Senate of my previous argument with relation to attaching to the Department of National Development those divisions of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation which deal with bush fires and the preservation of wild life. For 3 years now I have been advocating that the CSIRO Division of Wildlife Research should be attached to the Department of National Development to work in conjunction with the development of mineral resources and forest areas. While I appreciate that the Minister might have some doubts about constitutional difficulties, I do not think it is impossible to arrange for the establishment of a small secretariat to avoid some of the conflict that occurs when we are told that in the interests of progress some of the natural habitats of our wild life have to be sacrificed. I believe that a planned partnership could overcome these problems. 1 come now to the Division of National Mapping. 1 should like to know whether this Division undertakes aerial surveys and, if so, whether charter aircraft are used for the purpose.

talk.start.para: - Senator Mulvihill has referred to the Australian Forestry Council and the work done by its fire fighting seclion. The Australian Forestry Council is comprised of the Minister for National Development and the various State Ministers charged with the responsibility for forests. As the honourable senator has stated, our forestry fire expert has just returned from a visit to the United States of America and Canada where he witnessed demonstrations by water bomber aircraft. He reports that most of the aircraft being used on this work at the moment are former World War II aircraft which are now nearing the end of their serviceable life and that new types of aircraft are being developed. This is an important matter and the effectiveness of the new types of aircraft being developed overseas is being kept under close scrutiny. That is as far as we have gone in this work up to date.

speech.para: The honourable senator also referred to the Wildlife Research Division of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. He suggests that it be transferred to the Department of National Development. I do not hold that view. The function of the Department of National Development is to assess and develop Australia's natural resources.

talk.start.para: - Canada has the set up that I suggest.

- That is so, but I am doubtful about the wisdom of transferring the Wildlife Research Division to the Department of National Development although I do appreciate that the preservation of wild life is an important matter. I have listened to the honourable senator's advocacy in this chamber over some years now and I know his interest in the preservation of our wild life. I share that interest fully with him, but I feel that this matter is better left with the CSIRO. I appreciate his point that when we are carrying out developmental works either in our mineral areas or in our forests we should keep in mind the necessity and practicability, of taking steps to preserve our wild life. In the United Kingdom for instance, wild life is sometimes transferred to other areas. I appreciate that, through neglect in former years, some forms of our wild life have become extinct. This is a very interesting matter, but I believe that the preservation of wild life should be left in the hands of the CSIRO.

It is proposed to expend $3,500 on the hire of light aircraft for second order traverse reconnaissance in Western Australia and $13,500 on the hire of a helicopter in Western Australia for second order traverse during August and September 1967. The total amount involved in these programmes is $151,000.

The honourable senator referred to use of limestone in New South Wales. I am sorry that I cannot give him any information beyond that contained in the answer I gave to him on the occasion when he last referred to the matter.

- I would be happy to help. If the honourable senator wants to know the locality of other areas of limestone which can be worked economically, I am sure that the Bureau of Mineral Resources will be happy to tell him. But he will have to evince the interest.
- I have sent the State Minister the latest bulletin but I think it wants ministerial backing.

- I think the honourable senator has given the Minister all the information he is entitled to at the moment and I thank him for the help he has given to me in this work. If the honourable senator has any difficulty I am sure the Bureau of Mineral Resources will be only too happy to let him know what limestone resources there are.

- I should also like to refer to the use in the United States of America of Convair aircraft to study the extent to which lightning may -be responsible for starting forest fires. I am wondering whether the Commonwealth experts looked at this aspect when they were overseas. It may be that the methods being investigated over there would not be practicable here because of the different variety of trees but I did notice an article in either 'Time* or 'Newsweek' within the last. 6 or 7 weeks which indicated that the Americans were on the verge of a breakthrough in the use of cloud seeding to prevent forest fires. I am wondering whether our experts have any information on this matter?

- I refer to Division No. 932 - Department of National Development - Capital Works and Services. The appropriation for 1967-68 for this Department is some $3.3m less than expenditure last year. I should have thought that national development would have been the most important thing in Australia today having regard to the situation in which Australia finds itself, particularly in relation to drought. There is also a reduction of $2.5m in the allocation to the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. The total reduction probably amounts to more than that because at the foot of page 11 of Appropriation Bill (No. 2) is a note which reads: 'In addition $4,449,797 charged to Loan Fund'.

speech.para: The whole world is becoming very interested in the development of atomic energy. A considerable sum of money is being spent in America on what is known as the Plowshare scheme, and there is a degree of agitation in Australia for atomic energy to be used on water conservation projects and the development of harbours. I should have thought that this Government would have been anxious to develop atomic energy in Australia. The comparatively small expenditure of $1,629,000 last year under the Atomic Energy Act has been reduced by $300,000 this year, at a time when there is talk that within the next decade there will be atomic energy in Victoria and a requirement for atomic energy in South Australia. In addition, if we are to develop the minerals in the north of Western Australia to the processing stage it is quite likely that we will require atomic energy in that area. Yet expenditure has been cut to the extent of $300,000.

It is not my purpose at this stage to argue the merits of the Chowilla Dam which happens to be one of the tragedies of this Government's bad planning in relation to State water supplies. Proposed expenditure under the River Murray Waters Act has been reduced from $645,000 last year to $315,000 this year. I do not know whether the Government is trying to recover on the side part of the $5m which has been spent on the Chowilla Dam. Although water is the most precious commodity that we have in Australia we find this considerable reduction in proposed expenditure. The conservation of water is the most important subject that should be exercising the mind of any responsible Commonwealth government because today we have three States - South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales - experiencing a severe drought. National development, particularly in the field of water conservation, is something in which the Government should be taking a much keener interest. If it took as much interest in water conservation as it does in maintaining good relations with the United States we might be able to develop this country.

talk.start.para: - Water not war.

- We might be able to put out the fires of war with water if we had the water to produce enough food to feed the hungry millions in the world today. If we could do that there perhaps would not be the rush for nationalisation that we see in so many countries. I should like some explanation from the Minister for the reductions in proposed expenditure that I have mentioned. I -shall list them.

speech.para: In the first place, expenditure on plant and equipment in the Department of National Development is being reduced by $100,000. Secondly, proposed expenditure under the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act is being reduced by $2.5m. I appreciate that the Authority is in the winding up stage and that in the next 5 years it will cease to exist. The brains that we have been able to gather together over the years to perform one of the major engineering projects in the world - something of which Australia is proud - will be spread probably throughout the world, cer tainly throughout Australia. But even though the scheme is drawing to a close there is plenty of work upon which the specialists we have gathered together in the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority could be engaged. The Minister may say that the $2.5m reduction is the result of a slackening off in work on the scheme but that is not sufficient to satisfy the people of Australia. There should be an ever-expanding process of employment of these specialists on other projects.

Thirdly, the people of Australia, and indeed this Parliament, are entitled to know why expenditure under the Atomic Energy Act is being reduced by some $300,000 particularly in these days of vital development in the peaceful uses of atomic energy. Finally, I am sure that the Premier and the people of South Australia would be very interested to know why expenditure under the River Murray Waters Act is also being reduced by $300,000.

talk.start.para: - Senator Mulvihill raised the question of seeding clouds from Convair aircraft. I am advised that this matter was not studied specifically by our representative who was overseas and has returned only in the last few days but we will pursue our inquiries to see whether he has any information on it. Senator Cant referred to the proposed expenditure of $41,582,000 by the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority in 1967-68. That is the amount required to enable the Authority to carry out its programme of work in that year. As he said, the work is now tapering off and it is only to be expected that smaller sums of money will be required. He referred also to the Chowilla Dam. I take him up on that. This has nothing to do with the Commonwealth Government. The planning was done by the South Australian authorities. The River Murray Commission comprises representatives of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, and the Commonwealth Minister for National Development acts as Chairman. The project is under review at the moment. Its development is in abeyance whilst further investigations of it are being made. We debated this matter in this chamber only quite recently. Tt was a very interesting debate.
- Does not the Commonwealth expenditure on that project come under a special Act?
- The Commonwealth meets one-quarter of the cost.
- But that is under a special Act, not under these appropriations, is it not?

- I am advised that it is not under a special Act. The Commonwealth meets one-quarter of the cost. The rest is met by the States of Victoria. New South Wales and South Australia. It is quite wrong for Senator Cant to say that this deferment is the result of Commonwealth Government bungling. It is nothing of the sort. At the request of the States, the Commonwealth Government is meeting onequarter of the cost. The River Murray Commission handed over to the South Australian authorities responsibility lor the completion of the plans and specifications for this dam. That work was done by the South Australian authorities, who made an estimate of about $28m, if my memory serves me correctly. Later they amended the estimate to $43m. Then, on the basis of the work done by the South Australian Authorities, tenders were called and they showed a cost of about $70m.

speech.para: The project is now being reviewed by the River Murray Commission, an independent authority on which New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria are represented and on which the Commonwealth has a representative because it has accepted responsibility for meeting one-quarter of the cost. So 1 must take Senator Cant up on this matter and say that he is quite wrong when he says that this deferment is the result of bungling by the Commonwealth Government. It is nothing of the sort. For various reasons an attempt has been made to saddle the Federal Government with the blame for this deferment, but the project has nothing to do with the Federal Government, except that it meets, one-quarter of the cost.

I believe that out of the review that the River Murray Commission is now undertaking will come a far more satisfactory solution for South Australia and the people who will use this water. The area required may be a little less than was thought at first, as a result of the investigations that are now taking place. I do not pose as an authority on this project, but because it was mentioned in this chamber - and because I am interested in this type of work

I have read a good deal about it. I believe that out of this review will come a scheme that will be more acceptable than the present one which, at a cost of about $70m, docs not seem to be as satisfactory as it should be.

Senator Cantreferred to a reduction in the capital works and services appropriation for the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. The reduction is due to a decrease in construction expenditure in 1967-68 because of the completion of some major projects. That decrease is partly offset by an increased provision for scientific plant and equipment. In other words, the construction of some buildings has been completed and the Commission is now purchasing plant and equipment to go into those buildings. This is part of the planned construction programme.

An examination of the point that Senator Cant raised in relation to the Atomic Energy Commission leads me to say that in the next 10 years there will be great development in the use of atomic energy for peaceful purposes including power. I think that is accepted by all authorities. When the Commonwealth was considering making money available to the Tasmanian Government for the Gordon River scheme - $48m was made available in the form of bridging finance - I asked the Department of National Development to investigate that scheme vis a vis the use of atomic energy by the time it was finished. I am indebted to the officers of the Department. They gave me an excellent report to the effect that it would appear that it will be 10 years before atomic plants become economically competitive in the production of electricity. They considered that the Gordon River scheme would be of great economic benefit to Tasmania. But atomic plants are undoubtedly coming. They will be of great benefit in outlying areas of Australia. In America at the present time smaller plants are being developed. They could be situated in various parts of the Australian outback and could give a considerable boost to development.

I would not like anyone to think that the Australian Atomic Energy Commission is not keeping closely in touch with the developments in this field. If Senator Cant wants any advice on this matter, I would strongly advise him to put his problems to the Commission. He will receive the same help as I received in trying to assess whether the Commonwealth should provide bridging finance to the extent of $48m to the Tasmanian Government and the HydroElectric Commission and whether the Commonwealth should use the money of the Australian taxpayers in that way without first knowing the economics of the great Gordon River scheme and whether atomic energy could compete or more than compete with hydro-electric power in the years that lie ahead. The departmental officers satisfied me on that question. I am greatly indebted to them for what they did. 1 am sure that if Senator Cant wanted any further information on this matter the departmental officers would make it available to him. I think I have covered fairly well all the matters that Senator Cant raised. If I have missed any, I would like him to tell me now so that I can do what I can to answer any questions that I have omitted to answer.

talk.start.para: - I wish to refer briefly to an aspect of naval administration. I refer to the

speech.para: Navy's policy of stockpiling spare parts for the Charles F. Adams class destroyers.

talk.start.para: - I rise to order. We will be dealing tomorrow with the estimates for the Department of the Navy. Could the honourable senator reserve this matter until then?
- The Standing Orders require that when a point of order has been taken, the honourable senator having the call should resume his seat. I ask that the Standing Orders be observed.
- I do not wish to deprive Senator Mulvihill of anything, but as we will be dealing tomorrow with the estimates for the Department of the Navy, perhaps he could raise this matter then.

- Nobody knows whether the projected schedule will be followed tomorrow. I am informed that due to an error on the part of the people who went to the United States to purchase the Charles F. Adams destroyers, when certain furnace repairs are being done in Australia on these destroyers, the American fire brick is not available. Instead of the numbered fire brick being available, considerable improvisation is necessary. 1 do not belittle the efforts of our artificers or ordnance staff. It is obvious that the people whom we sent overseas to shop for this sophisticated defence equipment committed a grave error in not ensuring that the United States manufactured fire brick was available in Australia. What assurance have we that this oversight will be rectified? The Navy is not on a war footing but this oversight in not providing the correct fire bricks is not a good advertisement for the procurement methods employed by the Navy. I do not doubt the ability of our craftsmen to improvise but I do not think this should be necessary. Senator Bishop and I know something about the use of fire bricks in locomotive fire boxes. We know that the wrong brick can lead to a lot of difficulty.
- He has not been inside a fire box.
- Who has not?
- Senator Bishop.
- We can soon settle that. There has been a degree of oversight on the part of somebody. I look forward to an explanation and to an assurance that this will not happen in the future.

- Senator Mulvihill paid me the courtesy of informing me that he intended to raise this matter. I was able to get some information for him. Fire bricks fitted to the Royal Australian Navy guided missile destroyers are, naturally, made to United States Navy specifications. To ensure serviceability to the guided missile destroyers an initial supply of spares was obtained from the United States. However, the United States Navy specifications for the guided missile destroyer fire brick requirements have been obtained and following satisfactory manufacture of fire bricks, future requirements will be obtained locally.
